CLIProxyAPI Transform Your AI Subscriptions into Universal API Endpoints

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

CLIProxyAPI: Transform Your AI Subscriptions into Universal API Endpoints

Section titled “CLIProxyAPI: Transform Your AI Subscriptions into Universal API Endpoints”

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI coding tools, developers often face a fragmentation problem: premium subscriptions are locked behind OAuth authentication, while many tools and SDKs expect standard API keys. CLIProxyAPI elegantly solves this bridge by converting OAuth-based AI services into universal API endpoints.

What is CLIProxyAPI?

Section titled “What is CLIProxyAPI?”

CLIProxyAPI is an open-source proxy server written in Go that wraps multiple AI CLI tools and exposes them through standardized API interfaces. It transforms your existing AI subscriptions into OpenAI/Gemini/Claude-compatible APIs, eliminating the need for separate API keys.

Project: router-for-me/CLIProxyAPI License: MIT Language: Go (99.7%)

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

1. Multi-Provider OAuth Integration

Section titled “1. Multi-Provider OAuth Integration”

CLIProxyAPI supports OAuth authentication for leading AI services:

  • Claude Code - Anthropic’s Claude models via OAuth
  • ChatGPT / OpenAI Codex - GPT series models
  • Gemini CLI - Google’s Gemini models
  • Qwen Code - Alibaba’s Qwen models
  • iFlow - Additional AI service support
  • Antigravity - Alternative AI provider

2. Universal API Compatibility

Section titled “2. Universal API Compatibility”

The proxy provides standardized endpoints compatible with:

  • OpenAI API format
  • Gemini API format
  • Claude API format
  • Codex API format

This means your existing OpenAI SDK code works without modification—just change the base URL.

3. Advanced Account Management

Section titled “3. Advanced Account Management”
  • Multi-account support with round-robin load balancing
  • Hot reload configuration changes take effect without restart
  • OAuth session management with automatic token refresh
  • Model mapping for intelligent fallback (e.g., claude-opus-4.5 → claude-sonnet-4)

4. Comprehensive Feature Set

Section titled “4. Comprehensive Feature Set”
  • Streaming and non-streaming responses
  • Function calling / tools support
  • Multimodal input (text and images)
  • Management API for runtime configuration
  • Reusable Go SDK for embedding
  • Docker containerization support

Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration

Section titled “Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration”

System Requirements

Section titled “System Requirements”
  • Go 1.21+ (for building from source)
  • Docker (optional, for containerized deployment)
  • Valid subscriptions for supported AI services

Installation Methods

Section titled “Installation Methods”

Method 1: Build from Source

Section titled “Method 1: Build from Source”

Method 2: Docker Deployment

Section titled “Method 2: Docker Deployment”

Method 3: Pre-built Binaries

Section titled “Method 3: Pre-built Binaries”

Download from the Releases page (393 releases available).

Quick Configuration

Section titled “Quick Configuration”
  1. Configure OAuth Providers

Edit the configuration file to add your OAuth accounts:

  1. Start the Server
  1. Use Standard OpenAI SDK

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

Use Case 1: AI Coding Tool Integration

Section titled “Use Case 1: AI Coding Tool Integration”

Use your Claude Code or ChatGPT subscription with tools that only support API keys:

  • Claude Code desktop app
  • Cline VS Code extension
  • Roo Code assistant
  • Continue.dev autopilot

Use Case 2: Multi-Account Load Balancing

Section titled “Use Case 2: Multi-Account Load Balancing”

Distribute requests across multiple accounts to maximize usage limits:

Use Case 3: Cost Optimization

Section titled “Use Case 3: Cost Optimization”

Leverage free-tier subscriptions from multiple providers:

  • Google Gemini (free tier available)
  • Claude Code subscription
  • OpenAI ChatGPT Plus

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Security First: Management endpoints are localhost-only by design
  2. Model Fallback: Configure intelligent model mapping for availability
  3. Monitor Usage: Use the Management API to track account quotas
  4. Hot Reload: Modify configuration without service interruption

Ecosystem and Related Projects

Section titled “Ecosystem and Related Projects”

CLIProxyAPI has inspired a rich ecosystem of companion tools:

ProjectDescription
vibeproxyNative macOS menu bar app for Claude Code & ChatGPT
ProxyPalmacOS GUI for managing CLIProxyAPI configuration
QuotioMenu bar app with quota tracking and auto-failover
CodMateSwiftUI app for CLI AI session management
Subtitle TranslatorBrowser-based subtitle translation tool

Comparison with Similar Tools

Section titled “Comparison with Similar Tools”

vs. Direct API Keys

Section titled “vs. Direct API Keys”
AspectCLIProxyAPIDirect API Keys
CostUses existing subscriptionsSeparate billing
AuthenticationOAuth (no keys to manage)API key management
Multi-providerUnified endpointSeparate SDKs needed
Load balancingBuilt-inManual implementation

vs. Other Proxy Solutions

Section titled “vs. Other Proxy Solutions”
FeatureCLIProxyAPIAlternatives
OAuth Providers6+ supportedUsually 1-2
Open SourceMIT LicenseOften proprietary
Go SDKEmbeddableStandalone only
DocumentationEnglish + ChineseEnglish only

Precautions, FAQ and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions, FAQ and Troubleshooting”

Common Issues

Section titled “Common Issues”

Q: OAuth token expires frequently

A: CLIProxyAPI handles automatic token refresh. Ensure your OAuth credentials are valid and check system time synchronization.

Q: Model not available

A: Use model mapping to route unavailable models to alternatives:

Q: Rate limiting errors

A: Enable multi-account load balancing to distribute requests across accounts.

Security Considerations

Section titled “Security Considerations”
  • Management API endpoints bind to localhost only
  • OAuth tokens are stored securely
  • Never expose your proxy to public internet without authentication
  • Regular audit logs track all API requests

Troubleshooting Tips

Section titled “Troubleshooting Tips”
  1. Check logs: tail -f cliproxyapi.log
  2. Verify OAuth sessions via Management API
  3. Test with simple curl command first
  4. Ensure firewall allows localhost communication

Reference Links

Section titled “Reference Links”
  • GitHub Repository: https://github.com/router-for-me/CLIProxyAPI
  • Documentation: https://help.router-for.me/
  • Management API: https://help.router-for.me/management/api
  • Chinese README: README_CN.md
  • Community Guides: linux.do tutorials

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

CLIProxyAPI represents a pragmatic solution to AI service fragmentation, transforming OAuth-based subscriptions into universal API endpoints. Whether you’re integrating with coding tools, balancing load across accounts, or simply avoiding API key management, CLIProxyAPI provides a robust, open-source foundation.

With active development (1,239+ commits), comprehensive documentation in both English and Chinese, and a growing ecosystem of companion tools, CLIProxyAPI is poised to become an essential utility in the AI developer’s toolkit.

CodMate: The Ultimate macOS Session Manager for CLI AI Tools

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

If you’re a developer who uses CLI-based AI tools like Claude Code, Codex, or Gemini CLI, you know the pain of managing hundreds of scattered session files. Finding that brilliant solution from last Tuesday, resuming a suspended project context, or even just reviewing what you accomplished can be frustrating.

Enter CodMate—a native macOS SwiftUI application that brings order to your AI coding chaos. Built with performance in mind and designed for developers who value their time, CodMate transforms how you interact with your AI programming assistants.

What is CodMate?

Section titled “What is CodMate?”

CodMate is a session manager for CLI AI tools that provides:

  • Multi-source session browsing supporting Codex, Claude Code, and Gemini CLI
  • Blazing-fast search with incremental indexing and caching
  • Compact three-column UI designed for efficient workflow
  • “Ship it” workflows like Project Review with Git Changes
  • One-click Resume/New functionality

Built with Swift 6 and SwiftUI, CodMate leverages macOS 13.5+ APIs to deliver a truly native experience with universal binary support (Apple Silicon + Intel).

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Lightning-Fast Search & Navigation

Section titled “Lightning-Fast Search & Navigation”

CodMate’s global search panel (⌘F) offers scoped search with progress/cancel capabilities, plus quick list filtering. The app uses:

  • Memory-mapped reads for fast path indexing
  • Incremental parsing (first ~64 lines + tail sampling)
  • Background enrichment with constrained task groups
  • Chunked full-text search (128 KB) that avoids loading entire files

Project & Task Organization

Section titled “Project & Task Organization”

Keep your work organized with:

  • Projects that group sessions by repository
  • Tasks that group sessions by goal
  • Shareable task context files for team collaboration
  • Auto-assignment for new sessions in active projects

Terminal Integration

Section titled “Terminal Integration”

Resume sessions directly into your preferred terminal:

  • Terminal.app
  • iTerm2
  • Warp
  • Embedded terminal (non-sandbox builds)

Project Review (Git Changes)

Section titled “Project Review (Git Changes)”

One of CodMate’s most powerful features is the Project Review mode, which shows:

  • Changed files with stage/unstage support
  • Unified diff or raw preview
  • Commit UI with AI-powered commit message generation
  • On-demand repo authorization

MCP Server Management

Section titled “MCP Server Management”

CodMate includes comprehensive MCP server support:

  • Uni-Import (paste/drag JSON configuration)
  • Per-server enable toggles
  • Per-target toggles (Codex/Claude/Gemini)
  • Connectivity testing
  • Automatic export to ~/.claude/settings.json

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Download

Section titled “Download”

Latest version: 0.4.2

Download for Apple Silicon | Download for Intel Mac

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • macOS 13.5 or later
  • Swift 6 toolchain
  • Xcode Command Line Tools
  • Your preferred AI CLI (Codex / Claude / Gemini) installed

Architecture & Performance

Section titled “Architecture & Performance”

CodMate is built with clean architecture principles:

Performance highlights:

  • Persistent SQLite index for fast launches
  • Actor-based services for safe concurrency
  • Cancel-able tasks with proper cancellation guards
  • File IO prefers memory-mapped data and chunked reads

Section titled “Keyboard Shortcuts”

Section titled “1. Finding That Perfect Solution”

  1. Press ⌘F for global search
  2. Type a keyword from the solution
  3. Results appear instantly with context snippets
  4. Click to view the full conversation

Section titled “2. Project Continuity”

Starting a new workday on a project:

  1. Open CodMate and select your project from the sidebar
  2. See all related sessions grouped by task
  3. Review yesterday’s progress in the timeline
  4. One-click Resume to continue exactly where you left off

Section titled “3. Code Review Before Commit”

Ready to commit your AI-assisted changes:

  2. See all changed files with diffs

  4. Use AI to generate a descriptive commit message
  5. Commit without leaving the app

Precautions & Limitations

Section titled “Precautions & Limitations”

Known Limitations

Section titled “Known Limitations”
  • macOS-only: No Windows or Linux support currently planned
  • CLI dependency: Requires the underlying CLI tools to be installed separately
  • Sandbox considerations: Some features (embedded terminal, direct file access) are limited in sandboxed builds

Storage Locations

Understanding where CodMate stores data:

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Does CodMate modify my session files?

A: No, CodMate only reads session files. Notes, project assignments, and other metadata are stored separately.

Q: Can I use CodMate with multiple CLI tools simultaneously?

A: Yes! CodMate supports Codex, Claude Code, and Gemini CLI concurrently.

Q: Is my session data sent anywhere?

A: CodMate is local-first. Your session data never leaves your Mac unless you explicitly use features that call external APIs (like AI commit message generation).

Q: How does CodMate handle large session files?

A: CodMate uses intelligent parsing—reading only what’s needed for display, with background enrichment for full content. This keeps the UI fast even with thousands of sessions.

  • Language: Swift 99.1%

If you live in the terminal with Claude Code, Codex, or Gemini CLI, CodMate is the tool that brings order to the chaos—letting you focus on building rather than hunting for that one perfect response from last week.

doocs/cose: One-Click Markdown Publishing to 13+ Content Platforms

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

doocs/cose: One-Click Markdown Publishing to 13+ Content Platforms

Section titled “doocs/cose: One-Click Markdown Publishing to 13+ Content Platforms”

“Write once, publish everywhere” - the dream of every content creator.

If you’re a technical writer, developer, or content creator who publishes across multiple platforms, you know the pain of copying and pasting your content to each platform individually. Each platform has its own editor, formatting quirks, and login flow. It’s tedious, error-prone, and wastes valuable time.

doocs/cose solves this problem elegantly. As a browser extension designed for the popular doocs/md Markdown editor, cose enables one-click synchronization of your articles to 13+ content platforms simultaneously.

Introduction and Key Features

Section titled “Introduction and Key Features”

doocs/cose (short for “Content One-click SynchronizE”) is a browser extension developed by Yang Shuang (lead1314) that integrates seamlessly with the doocs/md Markdown editor. Its mission is simple: eliminate the friction of multi-platform content publishing.

Core Philosophy

Section titled “Core Philosophy”
  • 100% Local Operation - No data collection, no cloud storage, complete privacy
  • Write Once, Publish Everywhere - Edit in Markdown, sync to all platforms
  • Automatic Tab Management - Synced tabs are grouped for easy organization
  • Style Preservation - Especially for WeChat Official Account with full rendering

Supported Platforms (13+)

Section titled “Supported Platforms (13+)”
CategoryPlatforms
Social MediaWeChat Official Account, Zhihu, Jianshu
Tech CommunitiesCSDN, Juejin, SegmentFault (思否), OSChina
Media PlatformsToutiao (今日头条), Baijiahao (百家号), NetEase (网易号)
EnterpriseTencent Cloud (腾讯云), 51CTO, InfoQ
TraditionalCNBlogs (博客园)

Section titled “Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before installing cose, ensure you have:

  1. Google Chrome or a Chromium-based browser (Brave, Edge, etc.)
  2. Active accounts on the platforms you want to publish to
  3. doocs/md Markdown Editor - either the web version at md.doocs.org or a local development environment

Installation Methods

Section titled “Installation Methods”

Method 1: Chrome Web Store (Recommended)

Section titled “Method 1: Chrome Web Store (Recommended)”
  1. Visit the Chrome Web Store
  2. Search for “doocs/cose” or navigate directly from the GitHub repository
  3. Click “Add to Chrome”
  4. Grant necessary permissions

Method 2: Developer Mode

Section titled “Method 2: Developer Mode”

For testing the latest version or contributing:

First-Time Setup

Section titled “First-Time Setup”
  1. Install the Extension following one of the methods above
  2. Open doocs/md at md.doocs.org or your local instance
  3. Login to Platforms - Open each platform you want to publish to and login
  4. Grant Permissions - The extension will request necessary permissions on first use

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

Daily Workflow for Content Creators

Section titled “Daily Workflow for Content Creators”

Step 1: Write in Markdown

Section titled “Step 1: Write in Markdown”

Use doocs/md editor to craft your content:

Step 2: Preview and Refine

Section titled “Step 2: Preview and Refine”

The doocs/md editor provides real-time preview with:

  • Live rendering as you type
  • WeChat style preview for accurate formatting
  • Syntax highlighting for code blocks
  • Table editor for easy table creation

Step 3: One-Click Publish

Section titled “Step 3: One-Click Publish”
  1. Click the “Publish” (发布) button at the top of the editor
  2. A dialog appears showing all supported platforms
  3. Select the platforms you want to publish to
  4. Click “Confirm” (确定) to start synchronization

Step 4: Review and Manage

Section titled “Step 4: Review and Manage”
  • Tab Grouping: Synced tabs are automatically grouped
  • Login Detection: Extension shows which platforms you’re logged into
  • Draft Saving: WeChat articles are saved as drafts with full styling

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

  1. Platform-Specific Adjustments

    • Some platforms have title length limits
    • Image hosting varies (use external hosting for better compatibility)
    • Tags/keywords work differently per platform

  2. Content Organization

    • Use clear heading structures (H1, H2, H3)
    • Keep paragraphs concise for mobile readers
    • Test code blocks on platforms that support syntax highlighting

  3. WeChat Special Handling

    • cose preserves full rendering styles for WeChat
    • Articles are saved as drafts (not auto-published)
    • Review in WeChat editor before final publication

  4. Batch Publishing

    • Select multiple platforms at once
    • The extension handles each platform’s API differently
    • Monitor each tab for completion status

Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Precautions

Section titled “Precautions”
  1. Login Status: Ensure you’re logged into each platform before syncing
  2. Content Format: Some platforms may strip certain Markdown features
  3. Image Hosting: Use external image hosting (not local file references)
  4. Rate Limits: Some platforms may have anti-spam mechanisms
  5. Draft Review: Always review synced content, especially for WeChat

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is my content secure? A: Yes. The extension operates 100% locally. No data is collected or stored on external servers.

Q: Why did my sync fail on Platform X? A: Common reasons include: not logged in, network issues, platform API changes, or content format restrictions. Check the browser console for error details.

Q: Can I sync to platforms not listed? A: The project welcomes contributions. Submit an Issue or PR for new platform support.

Q: Does it work with local doocs/md? A: Yes, the extension works with both the web version at md.doocs.org and local development environments.

Q: What happens to code blocks? A: cose attempts to preserve code formatting, but syntax highlighting support varies by platform. Test on your target platforms first.

WeChat formatting brokenCheck for unsupported CSS features, review in WeChat editor

Liquid AI Cookbook: Examples, Tutorials and Apps Built with LFM Models

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

As artificial intelligence continues to evolve, the demand for efficient, deployable models that can run on edge devices has grown significantly. Liquid AI has emerged as a key player in this space with their open-weight LFM (Liquid Foundation Models) and the open-source LEAP SDK.

The Liquid AI Cookbook is a comprehensive repository containing examples, tutorials, and applications built with these technologies. Whether you’re looking to customize models, deploy to laptops and edge devices, or build complete applications, this cookbook provides the resources to get started.

What is Liquid AI?

Section titled “What is Liquid AI?”

Liquid AI is developing a new generation of hybrid models designed specifically for on-device deployment. Their LFM2 models range from 350M to 8B parameters, making them ideal for edge deployment while maintaining strong performance on agentic tasks, data extraction, RAG, creative writing, and multi-turn conversations.

Key Characteristics

Section titled “Key Characteristics”
  • Hybrid Architecture: Combines different modeling techniques for efficiency
  • On-Device First: Designed from the ground up for edge deployment
  • Specialized Models: Task-specific checkpoints for extraction, RAG, tool use, and math
  • Multi-Modal Support: Vision-language models (LFM2-VL) for visual understanding
  • Edge SDK: Native framework for mobile deployment (Android/iOS)

LFM2 Model Family

Section titled “LFM2 Model Family”

Text-to-Text Models

Section titled “Text-to-Text Models”

The LFM2 series is designed for agentic tasks and on-device deployment:

ModelSizeBest For
LFM2-8B-A1B8BComplex reasoning, multi-turn conversations
LFM2-2.6B2.6BBalanced performance and efficiency
LFM2-1.2B1.2BMobile deployment, real-time applications
LFM2-700M700MResource-constrained environments
LFM2-350M350MUltra-low latency scenarios

Specialized Nano Models

Section titled “Specialized Nano Models”

For specific use cases, Liquid AI offers specialized “nano” checkpoints:

LFM2-1.2B-ExtractData extraction from unstructured text (emails, filings, tickets)
LFM2-1.2B-RAGRAG applications, chatbots, knowledge base Q&A

A Python CLI that extracts structured data from invoice images using a 2-step agentic workflow. Perfect for automating document processing tasks.

Audio Transcription CLI

Section titled “Audio Transcription CLI”

Real-time audio-to-text transcription using LFM2-Audio-1.5B with llama.cpp integration. Ideal for meeting notes, podcast transcripts, and voice memos.

LEAP Edge SDK

Section titled “LEAP Edge SDK”

The LEAP Edge SDK is Liquid AI’s native framework for running LFM2 models on mobile devices. It provides:

  • Native Support: Android (Kotlin) and iOS (Swift)
  • Simple API: As easy as calling cloud LLM endpoints
  • Real-Time Streaming: Token streaming for responsive chat experiences
  • Persistent History: Built-in conversation management

When to Use LFM2 Models

Section titled “When to Use LFM2 Models”

Best for:

  • Agentic tasks and workflows
  • Data extraction and transformation
  • RAG applications
  • Tool use and function calling
  • Math reasoning (with specialized models)
  • On-device deployment
  • Mobile and edge applications

Not recommended for:

  • Complex programming tasks

Deployment Considerations

Section titled “Deployment Considerations”

Mobile/Edge:

  • Start with 1.2B or smaller for mobile devices
  • Use specialized models (Extract, RAG, Tool) for specific tasks
  • Consider the trade-off between model size and response quality

Desktop/Laptop:

  • 2.6B to 8B models provide good performance
  • More RAM allows for larger context windows
  • Consider GPU acceleration for better performance

The Liquid AI Cookbook represents an exciting development in the world of on-device AI. Whether you’re building a mobile app that needs local inference, creating an edge device solution, or simply want to experiment with efficient language models, the Liquid AI Cookbook offers the resources and examples to get started quickly.

llm-madness: A Lightweight Pipeline for Training Small GPT Models with Web UI

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

llm-madness: A Lightweight Pipeline for Training Small GPT Models with Web UI

Section titled “llm-madness: A Lightweight Pipeline for Training Small GPT Models with Web UI”

Training a custom GPT model from scratch typically requires complex infrastructure, expensive cloud resources, and specialized tooling. MaxHastings’ llm-madness inverts this assumption by providing a lightweight, end-to-end pipeline for training small GPT models locally, complete with a web-based UI for experiment management.

Introduction and Key Features

Section titled “Introduction and Key Features”

llm-madness is a Python-based toolkit that brings GPT model training within reach of individual developers and researchers. It provides everything needed to train custom language models: from BPE tokenizer training to model architecture design, from dataset management to run inspection—all through an intuitive web interface.

What Makes llm-madness Different

Section titled “What Makes llm-madness Different”
FeatureDescription
Complete PipelineData → Tokenizer → Tokenization → Training → Inspection
Web-Based UIVisual interface for configs, datasets, and run analysis
GPT ArchitectureClean, readable transformer implementation
Local-FirstNo cloud accounts or external services required
Experiment TrackingBuilt-in manifest system with provenance tracking

Core Capabilities

Section titled “Core Capabilities”
  1. Tokenizer Training - Configure BPE settings and build vocabularies from your own datasets
  2. Model Architecture - Design GPT-style transformers with configurable dimensions
  3. Dataset Management - Combine text files into versioned snapshots with SHA-256 hashing
  4. Training Infrastructure - AdamW optimizer with warmup, cosine decay, and checkpointing
  5. Run Inspection - Visualize loss curves, attention patterns, and token predictions
  6. Pipeline Orchestration - Chain stages together with automatic dependency resolution

Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration

Section titled “Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Python 3.8+ with pip
  • PyTorch for model training
  • (Optional) CUDA/MPS for GPU acceleration

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

The web UI will automatically load and display your latest training run.

Project Structure

Section titled “Project Structure”

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

Ideal Use Cases

Section titled “Ideal Use Cases”

1. Educational Learning

Understand transformer internals with a clean, readable implementation:

  • Visualize attention patterns per layer and head
  • Inspect token-level predictions during training
  • Debug model behavior with trace mode

2. Rapid Prototyping

Validate ideas quickly without infrastructure overhead:

  • Proof-of-concept models for specific tasks
  • Synthetic data experiments
  • Baseline establishment for comparison

3. Domain-Specific Tokenization

Train custom tokenizers on specialized corpora:

  • Code repositories for programming languages
  • Medical or legal texts
  • Mathematical notation
  • Any specialized vocabulary

4. Architecture Research

Experiment with model configurations:

  • Layer and head count variations
  • Embedding dimension tuning
  • Modern variants (RMSNorm, SwiGLU, RoPE)

Daily Workflow Example

Section titled “Daily Workflow Example”

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Start Small - Begin with tiny models (6 layers, 6 heads) to iterate quickly
  2. Version Everything - Use the manifest system to track experiments
  3. Monitor Closely - Check loss curves and samples during training
  4. Compare Runs - Use versioned configs for ablation studies
  5. Cache Tokens - Enable token cache to avoid re-tokenizing large datasets

Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Important Considerations

Section titled “Important Considerations”

⚠️ Not for Large-Scale Training

llm-madness is designed for small, reproducible experiments. It’s not suitable for:

  • Training models with billions of parameters
  • Distributed training across multiple GPUs
  • Production-scale inference

⚠️ GPU Memory Limits

Even “small” models require significant GPU memory:

  • A 6-layer, 6-head model may need 4-8GB VRAM
  • Consider reducing batch size or model dimensions if OOM occurs
  • CPU training is supported but much slower

⚠️ Training Data Quality

The quality of your output depends entirely on your training data:

  • Clean and preprocess text before training
  • Remove duplicates and low-quality content
  • Balance your dataset if training on multiple sources

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: What model sizes can I train?

A: llm-madness is optimized for models in the 1M-100M parameter range. Larger models may work but will be slow without significant GPU resources.

Q: Can I use pre-trained tokenizers?

A: The toolkit focuses on training custom BPE tokenizers, but you can modify the code to load pre-trained tokenizers like GPT-2’s.

Q: How do I enable GPU acceleration?

A: Install PyTorch with CUDA support. The toolkit automatically detects and uses CUDA if available, falling back to MPS (Apple Silicon) or CPU.

Q: Can I fine-tune existing models?

A: llm-madness is designed for training from scratch. For fine-tuning, consider tools like Hugging Face Transformers.

Q: What are the modern architecture flags?

A:

  • use_rmsnorm - RMSNorm instead of LayerNorm
  • use_swiglu - Gated FFN (SwiGLU) instead of GELU
  • use_rope - Rotary position embeddings
  • use_sdpa - Scaled dot-product attention (CUDA only)
  • use_kv_cache - Faster autoregressive generation

IssueSolution
CUDA out of memoryReduce batch size or model dimensions
Slow trainingEnable GPU acceleration or use smaller models
Poor generation qualityTrain longer, use more data, or adjust temperature
Tokenizer errorsCheck input file encoding and format
Web UI not loadingEnsure all dependencies are installed

The Unix Philosophy Was Right All Along: An IVP Analysis of 17 Timeless Rules

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

For over 50 years, the Unix philosophy has shaped how we build software. Its principles feel right in a way that transcends trends and languages. But why?

In “The Art of Unix Programming,” Eric Raymond distilled Unix wisdom into 17 rules. These aren’t arbitrary guidelines — they’re a coherent system based on one fundamental insight.

That insight is the Independent Variation Principle (IVP).

Let me show you why Unix got it right, and why these rules still matter in 2025.

What Is the Unix Philosophy?

Section titled “What Is the Unix Philosophy?”

The Unix philosophy emerged from the design of Unix at Bell Labs in the 1970s. Its core tenets:

  • Write programs that do one thing well
  • Write programs that work together
  • Write programs that handle text streams, because that is a universal interface

These ideas evolved into 17 specific rules documented in Raymond’s “The Art of Unix Programming” (2003). Each rule captures a different aspect of good design.

But here’s the question: Why do these rules work?

What Is IVP?

Section titled “What Is IVP?”

The Independent Variation Principle states:

Separate elements governed by different change drivers into distinct units; unify elements governed by the same change driver within a single unit.

Or more simply:

Separate what varies for different reasons; unite what varies for the same reason.

A change driver is a force that necessitates modifications: business requirements, user needs, technology evolution, performance constraints, regulatory compliance.

IVP’s insight: Systems minimize maintenance cost when their structure aligns with the structure of change forces.

When independent concerns are coupled, changes ripple unpredictably. When they’re separated, changes are localized.

The Problem: Why Does Software Rot?

Section titled “The Problem: Why Does Software Rot?”

Software degrades not because bits decay, but because reality changes:

  • Business needs evolve
  • Technologies advance
  • Users demand new features
  • Performance requirements shift
  • Security threats emerge
  • Regulations change

The challenge: Structure software so these independent forces don’t interfere with each other.

The Unix solution: The 17 rules are strategies for decoupling independent change drivers.

Let’s analyze each rule through the IVP lens.

The 17 Rules: An IVP Analysis

Section titled “The 17 Rules: An IVP Analysis”

1. Rule of Modularity: Write simple parts connected by clean interfaces

Section titled “1. Rule of Modularity: Write simple parts connected by clean interfaces”

The Rule:

Write simple parts connected by clean interfaces.

IVP Analysis:

Modules separate code by purpose. Clean interfaces separate specification from implementation.

Change drivers:

  • Module A’s internal logic (varies with A’s requirements)
  • Module B’s internal logic (varies with B’s requirements)
  • Interface contract (varies when coordination needs change)

These are independent. Module A’s implementation can change without affecting B, as long as the interface remains stable.

IVP verdict: ✅ Direct application of IVP-1 (Isolate Divergent Concerns)

Example:

Each program varies independently — grep’s pattern matching logic doesn’t affect wc’s counting logic.

2. Rule of Clarity: Clarity is better than cleverness

Section titled “2. Rule of Clarity: Clarity is better than cleverness”

The Rule:

Clarity is better than cleverness.

IVP Analysis:

Code has multiple change drivers:

  1. Functional requirements (what the code does)
  2. Comprehension requirements (understanding what it does)
  3. Modification requirements (changing what it does)

Clever code couples these drivers: optimizations that serve functional requirements often obscure comprehension, making modifications difficult.

IVP verdict: ✅ Optimizes for change driver alignment

Example:

3. Rule of Composition: Design programs to be connected to other programs

Section titled “3. Rule of Composition: Design programs to be connected to other programs”

The Rule:

Design programs to be connected to other programs.

IVP Analysis:

Change drivers:

  1. Individual program functionality (varies per program)
  2. Workflow requirements (varies with user tasks)

Monolithic programs couple these: adding a workflow requires modifying programs.

Composable programs decouple these: workflows combine existing programs without modification.

IVP verdict: ✅ Applies IVP-1 at the system level

Example:

4. Rule of Separation: Separate policy from mechanism; separate interfaces from engines

Section titled “4. Rule of Separation: Separate policy from mechanism; separate interfaces from engines”

The Rule:

Separate policy from mechanism; separate interfaces from engines.

IVP Analysis:

Change drivers:

  1. Policy (what decisions to make — business logic)
  2. Mechanism (how to execute decisions — implementation)
  3. Interface (how users interact — UX/API)
  4. Engine (how work is performed — algorithms)

These vary independently.

IVP verdict: ✅ Multiple applications of IVP-1

Example:

5. Rule of Simplicity: Design for simplicity; add complexity only where you must

Section titled “5. Rule of Simplicity: Design for simplicity; add complexity only where you must”

The Rule:

Design for simplicity; add complexity only where you must.

IVP Analysis:

Complexity couples change drivers. Every added feature increases the dependency surface.

Simplicity minimizes coupling by reducing the number of change drivers a component responds to.

IVP verdict: ✅ Minimizes change driver count

Simplicity is IVP optimization: fewer change drivers = fewer opportunities for coupling.

6. Rule of Parsimony: Write a big program only when it is clear by demonstration that nothing else will do

Section titled “6. Rule of Parsimony: Write a big program only when it is clear by demonstration that nothing else will do”

The Rule:

Write a big program only when it is clear by demonstration that nothing else will do.

IVP Analysis:

A “big program” typically means many coupled change drivers.

IVP verdict: ✅ Minimizes forced coupling

This rule says: don’t create coupling unless you’ve proven it’s unavoidable.

7. Rule of Transparency: Design for visibility to make inspection and debugging easier

Section titled “7. Rule of Transparency: Design for visibility to make inspection and debugging easier”

The Rule:

Design for visibility to make inspection and debugging easier.

IVP Analysis:

Change drivers:

  1. Program logic (varies with requirements)
  2. Debugging requirements (varies with failure modes)
  3. Monitoring requirements (varies with operational needs)

Transparent programs decouple these: state is visible without code changes.

IVP verdict: ✅ Decouples operation from observation

8. Rule of Robustness: Robustness is the child of transparency and simplicity

Section titled “8. Rule of Robustness: Robustness is the child of transparency and simplicity”

The Rule:

Robustness is the child of transparency and simplicity.

IVP Analysis:

This rule reveals a dependency relationship between change drivers:

  • Simplicity minimizes change drivers
  • Transparency decouples observation from logic
  • Together, they minimize unexpected interactions between change drivers

IVP verdict: ✅ Emergent property of IVP compliance

Robustness emerges when change drivers are properly decoupled — failures in one area don’t cascade to others.

9. Rule of Representation: Fold knowledge into data so program logic can be stupid and robust

Section titled “9. Rule of Representation: Fold knowledge into data so program logic can be stupid and robust”

The Rule:

Fold knowledge into data so program logic can be stupid and robust.

IVP Analysis:

Change drivers:

  1. Domain knowledge (what the system knows — business rules, configurations)
  2. Program logic (how the system operates — algorithms, control flow)

Data-driven design decouples these: domain knowledge lives in data, logic is generic.

IVP verdict: ✅ Applies IVP-1 via data/code separation

This is the Knowledge Theorem from IVP: cohesion increases when knowledge is explicit and separated by change driver.

10. Rule of Least Surprise: In interface design, always do the least surprising thing

Section titled “10. Rule of Least Surprise: In interface design, always do the least surprising thing”

The Rule:

In interface design, always do the least surprising thing.

IVP Analysis:

Change drivers:

  1. Interface behavior (how the program responds)
  2. User expectations (mental models, conventions)

IVP verdict: ✅ Minimizes interface change driver coupling

Following conventions separates “what this program does” from “how users expect it to work.”

11. Rule of Silence: When a program has nothing surprising to say, it should say nothing

Section titled “11. Rule of Silence: When a program has nothing surprising to say, it should say nothing”

The Rule:

When a program has nothing surprising to say, it should say nothing.

IVP Analysis:

Change drivers:

  1. Success path (normal operation)
  2. Failure path (error conditions)
  3. Monitoring/logging (operational visibility)

Silent-on-success programs decouple these: output signals exceptions, not normal operation.

IVP verdict: ✅ Separates signal from noise

12. Rule of Repair: When you must fail, fail noisily and as soon as possible

Section titled “12. Rule of Repair: When you must fail, fail noisily and as soon as possible”

The Rule:

When you must fail, fail noisily and as soon as possible.

IVP Analysis:

This rule complements Rule 11. Together they establish:

  • Silence = success (no change driver is active)
  • Noise = failure (error change driver is active)

IVP verdict: ✅ Localizes error change driver

Early failure prevents error change drivers from contaminating other change drivers.

13. Rule of Economy: Programmer time is expensive; conserve it in preference to machine time

Section titled “13. Rule of Economy: Programmer time is expensive; conserve it in preference to machine time”

The Rule:

Programmer time is expensive; conserve it in preference to machine time.

IVP Analysis:

Change drivers:

  1. Development cost (programmer time)
  2. Runtime cost (machine time)

IVP verdict: ✅ Prioritizes dominant change driver

This rule recognizes that development cost is the more frequent change driver — code changes more often than performance requirements.

14. Rule of Generation: Avoid hand-hacking; write programs to write programs when you can

Section titled “14. Rule of Generation: Avoid hand-hacking; write programs to write programs when you can”

The Rule:

Avoid hand-hacking; write programs to write programs when you can.

IVP Analysis:

Change drivers:

  1. Pattern specification (what to generate)
  2. Repetitive implementation (code instances)

Code generation decouples these: changing the pattern modifies the generator, instances regenerate automatically.

IVP verdict: ✅ Applies IVP-2 (Unify by Single Purpose)

15. Rule of Optimization: Prototype before polishing. Get it working before you optimize it

Section titled “15. Rule of Optimization: Prototype before polishing. Get it working before you optimize it”

The Rule:

Prototype before polishing. Get it working before you optimize it.

IVP Analysis:

Change drivers:

  1. Functional correctness (does it work?)
  2. Performance characteristics (is it fast?)

Premature optimization couples these: optimization complicates correctness.

IVP verdict: ✅ Sequences change drivers

This rule recognizes that change drivers have dependencies: correctness must be solved before performance can be meaningfully addressed.

16. Rule of Diversity: Distrust all claims for “one true way”

Section titled “16. Rule of Diversity: Distrust all claims for “one true way””

The Rule:

Distrust all claims for “one true way”.

IVP Analysis:

Different contexts have different change drivers:

  • Embedded systems: memory/power constraints
  • Web services: latency/throughput
  • Scientific computing: numerical accuracy
  • Databases: consistency/availability

IVP verdict: ✅ Recognizes context-dependent change drivers

This rule is meta-IVP: it acknowledges that change driver structure varies by context.

17. Rule of Extensibility: Design for the future, because it will be here sooner than you think

Section titled “17. Rule of Extensibility: Design for the future, because it will be here sooner than you think”

The Rule:

Design for the future, because it will be here sooner than you think.

IVP Analysis:

Change drivers:

  1. Current requirements (known today)
  2. Future requirements (anticipated)

IVP verdict: ✅ Optimizes for unknown future change drivers

Extensibility is IVP applied across time: separate today’s concerns from tomorrow’s.

The Pattern Is Clear

Section titled “The Pattern Is Clear”

All 17 rules serve one purpose: decouple independent change drivers.

RuleIVP PrincipleWhat It Decouples
ModularityIVP-1: IsolateModule internals from each other
ClarityOptimize for dominant driverLogic from comprehension
CompositionIVP-1: IsolatePrograms from workflows
SeparationIVP-1: IsolatePolicy/mechanism, interface/engine
SimplicityMinimize driversReduces coupling opportunities
ParsimonyMinimize forced couplingAvoids unnecessary shared change drivers
TransparencyIVP-1: IsolateLogic from observation
RobustnessEmergent propertyFailure isolation via decoupling
RepresentationIVP-1: IsolateKnowledge from logic (data/code)
Least SurpriseMinimize couplingBehavior from expectations
SilenceIVP-1: IsolateSuccess from monitoring
RepairIVP-1: IsolateErrors from normal flow
EconomyPrioritize driverDevelopment cost over runtime cost
GenerationIVP-2: UnifyPattern from instances
OptimizationSequence driversCorrectness before performance
DiversityContext-dependent driversSolutions across contexts
ExtensibilityFuture driversToday’s code from tomorrow’s needs

The Unix philosophy is systematic application of IVP.

Why Unix Endures

Section titled “Why Unix Endures”

Unix has outlived countless “next generation” systems because it aligns with fundamental change forces:

Text Streams Decouple Programs from Data Formats

Section titled “Text Streams Decouple Programs from Data Formats”

Programs don’t need to know about each other’s internal representations — text is the universal interface.

Small Tools Decouple Concerns

Section titled “Small Tools Decouple Concerns”

Each tool does one thing, responds to one change driver.

Pipes Decouple Composition from Implementation

Section titled “Pipes Decouple Composition from Implementation”

Workflows combine tools without coupling to their implementations.

Everything Is a File Decouples Programs from Resources

Section titled “Everything Is a File Decouples Programs from Resources”

Devices, sockets, files — all use the same interface.

These aren’t accidents. They’re deliberate decoupling strategies.

The Modern Relevance

Section titled “The Modern Relevance”

“But we’re not writing Unix utilities in 2025!”

True. But the change drivers are the same:

  • Requirements still evolve
  • Technologies still advance
  • Teams still need to work in parallel
  • Code still needs maintenance

IVP explains why Unix principles transfer to modern contexts:

Microservices = Rule of Modularity

Section titled “Microservices = Rule of Modularity”

Independent services = independent change drivers (team autonomy, deployment independence).

APIs = Text Streams

Section titled “APIs = Text Streams”

JSON/HTTP = universal interface, decoupling services from internal representations.

Containers = Rule of Extensibility

Section titled “Containers = Rule of Extensibility”

Docker images decouple application code from infrastructure.

Infrastructure as Code = Rule of Representation

Section titled “Infrastructure as Code = Rule of Representation”

Configuration as data decouples infrastructure from manual setup.

CI/CD = Rule of Generation

Section titled “CI/CD = Rule of Generation”

Automated pipelines decouple deployment from manual steps.

The principles are timeless because change drivers are timeless.

The Lesson

Section titled “The Lesson”

The Unix philosophy wasn’t arbitrary wisdom from bearded wizards. It was systematic engineering:

  1. Identify independent change drivers (requirements, technology, users, operations)
  2. Structure systems to decouple them (modularity, composition, interfaces)
  3. Minimize coupling (simplicity, parsimony, separation)
  4. Maximize independence (extensibility, diversity, generation)

This is IVP in action.

Unix got it right because it aligned with how software actually changes.

The Bottom Line

Section titled “The Bottom Line”

The Unix philosophy has one message:

Structure systems so independent concerns can vary independently.

That’s IVP.

The 17 rules are strategies for achieving this. They’re not commandments — they’re implications of IVP applied to different design dimensions.

When you follow the Unix philosophy, you’re applying IVP, whether you know it or not.

And when you apply IVP consciously, you’ll make the same design decisions Unix pioneers made — because you’re aligning with the same fundamental forces.

Learn More

Section titled “Learn More”

The Independent Variation Principle is introduced in:

Loth, Y. (2025). The Independent Variation Principle. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.17677316

The paper provides:

  • Formal derivation of IVP from first principles
  • The Knowledge Theorem connecting cohesion to domain knowledge
  • Applications to OOP, FP, databases, and architectures
  • Rigorous analysis of coupling/cohesion metrics
  • Extensions beyond software design

Eric Raymond’s “The Art of Unix Programming” remains the definitive guide to Unix philosophy: http://www.catb.org/~esr/writings/taoup/html/

Source: Yannick Loth on dev.to

Agent Client: AI Coding Agents Directly in Your Obsidian Vault

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Agent Client is an Obsidian plugin that brings AI coding agents directly into your knowledge management workspace. Built on the Agent Client Protocol (ACP)—an open standard pioneered by the Zed editor—this plugin creates a seamless bridge between your personal knowledge base and powerful AI coding assistants like Claude Code, Codex, and Gemini CLI.

Instead of juggling between your notes and terminal, Agent Client integrates AI agents into a dedicated right-side panel within Obsidian, transforming your vault into an intelligent development companion.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

🤖 Direct Agent Integration

Section titled “🤖 Direct Agent Integration”

Chat with AI coding agents in a dedicated right-side panel without leaving Obsidian. Your AI assistant is just a side panel away.

📝 Note Mentions

Section titled “📝 Note Mentions”

Reference your Obsidian notes directly in conversations using @notename syntax. Automatically include the active note’s content or manually reference specific notes to provide context to your AI agent.

⚡ Slash Commands

Section titled “⚡ Slash Commands”

Quickly trigger agent actions using / commands. Browse and execute actions provided by your current agent without typing full prompts.

🔄 Multi-Agent Support

Section titled “🔄 Multi-Agent Support”

Switch between Claude Code, Codex, Gemini CLI, and any ACP-compatible custom agents. Configure multiple agents and switch between them based on your task requirements.

🎛️ Mode & Model Selection

Section titled “🎛️ Mode & Model Selection”

Change AI models (e.g., Sonnet, Haiku, Opus) and agent modes (e.g., Plan Mode) directly from the chat interface using convenient dropdown menus.

💻 Terminal Integration

Section titled “💻 Terminal Integration”

Let your agent execute shell commands and return results inline in the chat. Run build scripts, git commands, or any terminal operation without leaving the conversation.

🖼️ Image Attachments

Section titled “🖼️ Image Attachments”

Paste or drag-and-drop images directly into the chat to send them with your message—perfect for visual debugging or UI-related questions.

🔐 Permission Management

Section titled “🔐 Permission Management”

Fine-grained control over agent actions. Approve or deny file reads, edits, and command executions based on your comfort level.

Supported Agents

Section titled “Supported Agents”
AgentProviderIntegration Method
Claude CodeAnthropicvia Zed’s SDK adapter (@zed-industries/claude-code-acp)
CodexOpenAIvia Zed’s adapter (@zed-industries/codex-acp)

  2. In Obsidian settings, navigate to Community Plugins → BRAT → Add Beta Plugin
  3. Paste this repository URL:
  4. BRAT will download the latest release and keep it auto-updated
  5. Enable Agent Client from the plugin list

    • main.js

    • styles.css
  2. Create the plugin folder: VaultFolder/.obsidian/plugins/agent-client/
  3. Place the downloaded files in this folder
  4. Enable the plugin in Obsidian Settings → Community Plugins

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

Daily Workflow Integration

Section titled “Daily Workflow Integration”

  1. Code Review with Context: Open your project documentation in Obsidian, reference it with @notename, and ask Claude Code to review your implementation against the documented requirements.

  2. Debugging Session: When stuck on a bug, take a screenshot, paste it into the Agent Client chat, and let your AI agent analyze the error while you reference relevant error logs stored in your vault.

  3. Documentation Generation: As you build features, use the chat to generate documentation while the agent reads your code files—then save the output directly to your notes.

  4. Multi-Agent Task Switching: Use Claude Code for architectural planning, switch to Codex for code generation, and use Gemini CLI for alternative perspectives—all within the same interface.

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  • Organize Notes by Project: Structure your vault so that project-specific notes can be easily referenced with @notename
  • Use Chat Export: Save important conversations for future reference—Agent Client supports exporting chat history
  • Leverage Terminal Integration: Run tests and builds directly from the chat to get immediate feedback
  • Permission Management: Start with restrictive permissions and gradually grant access as trust builds with the agent

Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Precautions

Section titled “Precautions”
  • API Key Security: API keys are stored in Obsidian’s plugin settings. Enable vault encryption if storing sensitive keys
  • Terminal Commands: Agents can execute commands—review permissions carefully before approving
  • File Editing: Agents can modify files—always review proposed changes before applying

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Can I use multiple agents simultaneously? A: Currently, you can switch between agents, but future updates will include multi-instance support for running multiple agents simultaneously.

Q: Does this work on mobile? A: The plugin is designed for desktop Obsidian. Mobile support depends on Obsidian’s plugin capabilities on mobile platforms.

Q: Can I use custom agents? A: Yes! Any agent that implements the Agent Client Protocol (ACP) can be configured in the plugin settings.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Issue: Agent fails to start

  • Verify Node.js path is correct
  • Check that the agent is installed globally and accessible via which or where.exe
  • Ensure the agent executable has proper permissions

Issue: Images not sending

  • Check image format (PNG, JPG supported)
  • Verify image size is reasonable (< 10MB recommended)

Issue: Terminal commands not working

  • Approve terminal permissions when prompted
  • On Windows, consider using WSL mode for better Unix compatibility

Unique Advantage: Agent Client’s tight integration with Obsidian’s knowledge management makes it ideal for developers who maintain extensive documentation, research notes, or project specifications in their vault.

Roadmap

Section titled “Roadmap”

The developer has planned several exciting features:

  • Edit Tracking: Automatically follow agent edits—open affected notes and move the cursor as they edit
  • Chat History Access: Browse, search, and restore previous chat sessions with agents
  • Multi-Instance Support: Run multiple agents simultaneously in separate panels

Advent of Claude: 31 Days of Claude Code

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Throughout December, I shared one Claude Code tip per day on X/Twitter and LinkedIn. What started as a simple advent calendar became a map of the features that have fundamentally changed how I write software. This post compiles all 31 tips into a comprehensive guide, reorganized from beginner essentials to advanced patterns, and adds additional context that can’t be covered in 280 characters.

Whether you’re just getting started or looking to level up with Claude Code, there’s something here for you.

Getting Started

Section titled “Getting Started”

Before diving into features, set up Claude Code to understand your project.

/init — Let Claude Onboard Itself Onto Your Project

Section titled “/init — Let Claude Onboard Itself Onto Your Project”

Everybody needs onboarding docs. With /init, Claude writes its own.

Claude reads your codebase and generates a CLAUDE.md file with:

  • Build and test commands
  • Key directories and their purposes
  • Code conventions and patterns
  • Important architectural decisions

This is the first thing I run in any new project.

For larger projects, you can also create a .claude/rules/ directory for modular, topic-specific instructions. Each .md file in this directory is automatically loaded as project memory alongside your CLAUDE.md. You can even use YAML frontmatter to apply rules conditionally based on file paths:

Think of CLAUDE.md as your general project guide, and .claude/rules/ as focused supplements for testing, security, API design, or anything else that deserves its own file.

Memory Updates

Section titled “Memory Updates”

Want to save something to Claude’s memory without manually editing CLAUDE.md? As of Claude Code 2.0.70, just tell Claude to update the Claude.md file for you.

Just tell Claude to remember it:

“Update Claude.md: always use bun instead of npm in this project”

Keep coding without breaking your flow.

@ Mentions — Add Context Instantly

Section titled “@ Mentions — Add Context Instantly”

@ mentions are the fastest way to give Claude context:

  • @src/auth.ts — Add files to context instantly
  • @src/components/ — Reference entire directories
  • @mcp:github — Enable/disable MCP servers

File suggestions are ~3x faster in git repositories and support fuzzy matching. @ is the fastest path from “I need context” to “Claude has context.”

Essential Shortcuts

Section titled “Essential Shortcuts”

These are the commands you’ll use constantly. Commit them to muscle memory.

The ! Prefix — Run Bash Instantly

Section titled “The ! Prefix — Run Bash Instantly”

Don’t waste tokens asking “can you run git status?”

Just type ! followed by your bash command:

The ! prefix executes bash instantly and injects the output into context. No model processing. No delay. No wasted tokens. No need for multiple terminal windows.

This seems small until you realize you’re using it fifty times a day.

Double Esc to Rewind

Section titled “Double Esc to Rewind”

Want to try a “what if we…” approach without committing to it?

Go wild. If it gets weird, press Esc twice to jump back to a clean checkpoint.

You can rewind the conversation, the code changes, or both. One thing to note here is that Bash commands run cannot be undone.

Your past prompts are searchable:

KeyAction
Ctrl+RStart reverse search
Ctrl+R (again)Cycle through matches
EnterRun it
TabEdit first

Don’t retype. Recall. This works seamlessly with slash commands too.

Prompt Stashing

Section titled “Prompt Stashing”

It’s like git stash, but for your prompt.

Ctrl+S saves your draft. Send something else. Your draft auto-restores when you’re ready.

No more copying to a scratchpad. No more losing your train of thought mid-conversation.

Prompt Suggestions

Section titled “Prompt Suggestions”

Claude can predict what you’ll ask next.

Finish a task, and sometimes you’ll see a grayed-out follow-up suggestion appear:

KeyAction
TabAccept and edit
EnterAccept and run immediately

Tab used to autocomplete your code. Now it autocompletes your workflow. Toggle this feature via /config.

Session Management

Section titled “Session Management”

Claude Code is a persistent development environment and optimizing it to your workflow will allow you to do so much more.

Continue Where You Left Off

Section titled “Continue Where You Left Off”

Accidentally closed your terminal? Laptop died mid-task? No problem.

Context preserved. Momentum restored. Your work is never lost. You can also customize how long sessions are preserved via the cleanupPeriodDays setting. By default it is 30 days, but you can set it as long as you want, or even 0 if you don’t want to preserve your Claude Code sessions.

Named Sessions

Section titled “Named Sessions”

Your git branches have names. Your Claude sessions should too.

The /resume screen groups forked sessions and supports keyboard shortcuts: P for preview, R for rename.

Claude Code Remote

Section titled “Claude Code Remote”

Start a task on the web, finish it in your terminal:

This pulls and resumes the session locally. Claude at home and on the go. Also works via the Claude mobile app for iOS and Android, as well as the Claude Desktop app.

/export — Get Receipts

Section titled “/export — Get Receipts”

Sometimes you need a record of what happened.

/export dumps your entire conversation to markdown:

  • Every prompt you sent
  • Every response Claude gave
  • Every tool call and its output

Perfect for documentation, training, or proving to your past self that yes, you did already try that approach.

Productivity Features

Section titled “Productivity Features”

These features remove friction and help you move faster.

Vim Mode

Section titled “Vim Mode”

Tired of reaching for the mouse to edit your prompts?

Type /vim and unlock full vim-style editing:

CommandAction
h j k lNavigate
ciwChange word
ddDelete line
w bJump by word
AAppend at end of line

Edit prompts at the speed of thought. Your muscle memory from decades of vim use finally pays off in an AI tool. And it’s never been easier to exit vim with Claude Code, just type /vim again.

/statusline — Customize Your View

Section titled “/statusline — Customize Your View”

Claude Code has a customizable status bar at the bottom of your terminal.

/statusline lets you configure what appears there:

  • Git branch and status
  • Current model
  • Token usage
  • Context window percentage
  • Custom scripts

Information at a glance means fewer interruptions to check on things manually.

/context — X-Ray Vision for Tokens

Section titled “/context — X-Ray Vision for Tokens”

Ever wonder what’s eating your context window?

Type /context to see exactly what’s consuming your tokens:

  • System prompt size
  • MCP server prompts
  • Memory files (CLAUDE.md)
  • Loaded skills and agents
  • Conversation history

When your context starts filling up, this is how you figure out where it’s going.

/stats — Your Usage Dashboard

Section titled “/stats — Your Usage Dashboard”

Type /stats to see your usage patterns, favorite models, usage streaks, and more.

Orange is the new green.

/usage — Know Your Limits

Section titled “/usage — Know Your Limits”

“Am I about to hit my limit?”

Know your limits. Then exceed them.

Thinking & Planning

Section titled “Thinking & Planning”

Control how Claude approaches problems.

Ultrathink

Section titled “Ultrathink”

Trigger extended thinking on demand with a single keyword:

When you include ultrathink in your prompt, Claude allocates up to 32k tokens for internal reasoning before responding. For complex architectural decisions or tricky debugging sessions, this can be the difference between a surface-level answer and genuine insight.

In the past you were able to specify think, think harder, and ultrathink to allocate different amounts of tokens for thinking, but we’ve since simplified this into a single thinking budget. The ultrathink keyword only works when MAX_THINKING_TOKENS is not set. When MAX_THINKING_TOKENS is configured, it takes priority and controls the thinking budget for all requests.

Plan Mode

Section titled “Plan Mode”

Clear the fog of war first.

Press Shift+Tab twice to enter Plan mode. Claude can:

  • Read and search your codebase
  • Analyze architecture
  • Explore dependencies
  • Draft implementation plans

But it won’t edit anything until you approve the plan. Think twice. Execute once.

I default to plan mode 90% of the time. The latest version lets you provide feedback when rejecting plans, making iteration faster.

Extended Thinking (API)

Section titled “Extended Thinking (API)”

When using the Claude API directly, you can enable extended thinking to see Claude’s step-by-step reasoning:

Claude shows its reasoning in thinking blocks before responding. Useful for debugging complex logic or understanding Claude’s decisions.

Permissions & Safety

Section titled “Permissions & Safety”

Power without control is just chaos. These features let you set boundaries.

Sandbox Mode

Section titled “Sandbox Mode”

/sandbox lets you define boundaries once. Claude works freely inside them.

You get speed with actual security. The latest version supports wildcard syntax like mcp__server__* for allowing entire MCP servers.

YOLO Mode

Section titled “YOLO Mode”

Tired of Claude Code asking permission for everything?

This flag says yes to everything. It has “danger” in the name for a reason—use it wisely, ideally in isolated environments or for trusted operations.

Hooks

Section titled “Hooks”

Hooks are shell commands that run at predetermined lifecycle events:

  • PreToolUse / PostToolUse: Before and after tool execution
  • PermissionRequest: Automatically approve or deny permission requests
  • Notification: React to Claude’s notifications
  • SubagentStart / SubagentStop: Monitor agent spawning

Configure them via /hooks or in .claude/settings.json.

Use hooks to block dangerous commands, send notifications, log actions, or integrate with external systems. It’s deterministic control over probabilistic AI.

Automation & CI/CD

Section titled “Automation & CI/CD”

Claude Code works beyond interactive sessions.

Headless Mode

Section titled “Headless Mode”

You can use Claude Code as a powerful CLI tool for scripts and automation:

AI in your pipeline. The -p flag runs Claude non-interactively and outputs directly to stdout.

Commands — Reusable Prompts

Section titled “Commands — Reusable Prompts”

Save any prompt as a reusable command:

Create a markdown file, and it becomes a slash command that can additionally accept arguments:

Stop repeating yourself. Your best prompts deserve to be reusable.

Browser Integration

Section titled “Browser Integration”

Claude Code can see and interact with your browser.

Claude Code + Chrome

Section titled “Claude Code + Chrome”

Claude can now directly interact with Chrome:

  • Navigate pages
  • Click buttons and fill forms
  • Read console errors
  • Inspect the DOM
  • Take screenshots

“Fix the bug and verify it works” is now one prompt. Install the Chrome extension from claude.ai/chrome.

Advanced: Agents & Extensibility

Section titled “Advanced: Agents & Extensibility”

This is where Claude Code becomes truly powerful.

Subagents

Section titled “Subagents”

Santa doesn’t wrap every gift himself. He has elves.

Subagents are Claude’s elves. Each one:

  • Gets its own 200k context window
  • Performs specialized tasks
  • Runs in parallel with others
  • Merges output back to the main agent

Delegate like Santa. Subagents can run in the background while you continue working, and they have full access to MCP tools.

Agent Skills

Section titled “Agent Skills”

Skills are folders of instructions, scripts, and resources that teach Claude specialized tasks.

They’re packaged once and usable everywhere. And since Agent Skills are now an open standard, they work across any tool that supports them.

Think of skills as giving Claude expertise on demand. Whether that’s your company’s specific deployment process, a testing methodology, or a documentation standard.

Plugins

Section titled “Plugins”

Remember when sharing your Claude Code setup meant sending 47 files across 12 directories?

That era is over.

Plugins bundle commands, agents, skills, hooks, and MCP servers into one package. Discover new workflows via the marketplace, which includes search filtering for easier discovery.

Language Server Protocol (LSP) Integration

Section titled “Language Server Protocol (LSP) Integration”

Language Server Protocol (LSP) support gives Claude IDE-level code intelligence:

LSP integration provides:

  • Instant diagnostics: Claude sees errors and warnings immediately after each edit
  • Code navigation: go to definition, find references, and hover information
  • Language awareness: type information and documentation for code symbols

Claude Code now understands your code the way your IDE does.

Claude Agent SDK

Section titled “Claude Agent SDK”

The same agent loop, tools, and context management that power Claude Code are now available as an SDK. Build agents that work like Claude Code in as little as 10 lines of code:

This is just the beginning.

Quick Reference

Section titled “Quick Reference”

Closing Thoughts

Section titled “Closing Thoughts”

When I started this advent calendar, I thought I was just sharing tips. But looking back at these 31 days, I see something more: a philosophy of human-AI collaboration.

The best features in Claude Code are about giving you control. Plan mode. Agent Skills. Hooks. Sandbox boundaries. Session management. These are tools for working with AI, not surrendering to it.

The developers who get the most out of Claude Code aren’t the ones who type “do everything for me.” They’re the ones who’ve learned when to use Plan mode, how to structure their prompts, when to invoke ultrathink, and how to set up hooks that catch mistakes before they happen.

AI is a lever. These features help you find the right grip.

Here’s to 2026.

Boris Cheny's Claude Code Workflow Revealed: Running 15-20 Opus 4.5 Instances in Parallel

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Boris Cheny’s Claude Code Workflow Revealed: Running 15-20 Opus 4.5 Instances in Parallel

Section titled “Boris Cheny’s Claude Code Workflow Revealed: Running 15-20 Opus 4.5 Instances in Parallel”

“I’m Boris and I created Claude Code. Lots of people have asked how I use Claude Code, so I wanted to show off my setup a bit.”

— Boris Cherny, January 2, 2026

When the creator of Claude Code shares his personal workflow, the development community pays attention. Boris Cherny recently revealed his surprisingly “vanilla” yet highly sophisticated approach to maximizing AI-assisted development productivity.

Introduction: Compound Thinking and Verification

Section titled “Introduction: Compound Thinking and Verification”

At the core of Boris’s workflow are two fundamental mindsets:

  1. Compound Thinking - The CLAUDE.md file isn’t a one-time document but a continuously evolving knowledge base accumulated through daily work, code reviews, and problem discovery
  2. Verification Loops - Verification can improve output quality by 2-3x, addressing a core limitation in current AI programming: AI generates code well, but doesn’t inherently know if it actually works or provides good UX

Boris emphasizes: “A good plan is half the success” and invests heavily in upfront planning before switching to auto-accept mode for implementation.

Multi-Instance Parallelism: 15-20 Claude Instances Running Simultaneously

Section titled “Multi-Instance Parallelism: 15-20 Claude Instances Running Simultaneously”

Boris’s workstation runs at least 15 Claude instances concurrently:

EnvironmentInstancesPurpose
Terminal (iTerm2)5 tabsNumbered 1-5, using system notifications for attention management
Browser5-10 tabsclaude.ai/code sessions
TransportBidirectionalUsing & to transfer local sessions to web, --teleport for cross-session movement

This parallel workflow allows Boris to advance multiple tasks simultaneously, effectively orchestrating an intelligence matrix of AI agents.

Model Strategy: Opus 4.5 with Thinking Mode - Exclusively

Section titled “Model Strategy: Opus 4.5 with Thinking Mode - Exclusively”

Boris uses only Opus 4.5 with thinking mode enabled. His rationale is counterintuitive but proven:

“Although Opus is larger and slower, because of its strong understanding and accurate tool usage, it’s actually faster overall. No need for repeated corrections and guidance—it gets it right the first time. That’s true efficiency.”

The upfront cost of larger models pays dividends through reduced iteration cycles and higher-quality first-pass outputs.

Team Knowledge Base: Shared CLAUDE.md in Git

Section titled “Team Knowledge Base: Shared CLAUDE.md in Git”

The Claude Code team maintains a shared CLAUDE.md file committed to Git that every team member updates weekly. The logic is simple:

“Whenever you see Claude do something wrong, write it into CLAUDE.md. Next time Claude will know not to do that.”

This transforms team coding standards and collective experience into AI-accessible knowledge, creating a flywheel where:

  • Each code review improves CLAUDE.md
  • Improved CLAUDE.md automatically raises subsequent code quality
  • Knowledge compounds over time

Code Review Integration: @.claude PR Tags

Section titled “Code Review Integration: @.claude PR Tags”

During code reviews, Boris uses @.claude tags on colleagues’ PRs, instructing Claude to add discovered issues to CLAUDE.md. This is powered by Claude Code’s GitHub Action (installed via /install-github-action).

This is their version of “compound engineering”—every code review systematically improves the knowledge base, which then automatically improves future code quality.

Plan Mode: Discussion Before Implementation

Section titled “Plan Mode: Discussion Before Implementation”

Most sessions start with Plan mode (activated via double Shift+Tab). Boris discusses back and forth with Claude until satisfied with the plan, then switches to auto-accept edit mode where Claude typically completes implementation in one pass.

The pattern reinforces the principle: invest in planning, execute with confidence.

Slash Commands: Automating Inner Loop Workflows

Section titled “Slash Commands: Automating Inner Loop Workflows”

Boris has converted frequently repeated “inner loop” workflows into slash commands stored in .claude/commands/ and committed to Git:

  • Eliminates repetitive prompt engineering
  • Claude itself can invoke these commands
  • Team-wide standardization of workflows
  • Example: /verify command for validation workflows

Subagents: Common Workflow Automation

Section titled “Subagents: Common Workflow Automation”

Key subagents in Boris’s toolkit:

SubagentPurpose
code-simplifierSimplifies code after Claude completes work
verify-appContains detailed instructions for end-to-end Claude Code testing

Subagents essentially automate the most common workflows, ensuring every PR runs through standardized quality gates.

Post-Tool-Use Hook: Automatic Code Formatting

Section titled “Post-Tool-Use Hook: Automatic Code Formatting”

The team uses a Post-Tool-Use hook to auto-format Claude-generated code. Since Claude typically generates well-formatted code, the hook only handles the final ~10%, preventing CI format failures while maintaining code style consistency.

Permissions Management: Pre-Allow Rather Than Skip

Section titled “Permissions Management: Pre-Allow Rather Than Skip”

Boris doesn’t use --dangerously-skip-permissions. Instead, he uses /permissions to pre-allow common, safe bash commands in his environment, avoiding unnecessary permission prompts while maintaining security awareness.

Configuration is stored in .claude/settings.json and shared with the team via Git.

Tool Integration: Slack, BigQuery, Sentry

Section titled “Tool Integration: Slack, BigQuery, Sentry”

Claude Code integrates with Boris’s entire toolchain:

ToolIntegrationUse Case
SlackMCP serverSearch and post messages
BigQuerybq CLIRun queries for analysis
SentryDirect integrationFetch error logs

The Slack MCP configuration (.mcp.json) is also committed to Git for team sharing.

Long-Running Tasks: Background Agents and Stop Hooks

Section titled “Long-Running Tasks: Background Agents and Stop Hooks”

For extended tasks, Boris employs several strategies:

  1. Background agents for verification upon completion
  2. Agent Stop hooks for more deterministic verification
  3. Ralph-Wiggum plugin (originally conceived by Geoffrey Huntley)
  4. Sandbox mode with --permission-mode=dontAsk or --dangerously-skip-permissions for uninterrupted work

The Most Critical Insight: Give Claude Verification Feedback

Section titled “The Most Critical Insight: Give Claude Verification Feedback”

Boris’s most important insight:

“The most important thing is giving Claude a way to verify its work. With this feedback loop, final result quality improves 2-3x.”

The Claude Code team uses the Claude Chrome extension to test every change. Claude opens the browser, tests the UI, and iterates until code works and user experience is satisfactory.

Verification methods vary by domain—running a bash command, executing test suites, or testing in browser/mobile emulators—but investing in robust verification is universally applicable.

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

Daily Workflow Example

Section titled “Daily Workflow Example”

Best Practices

Precautions and Common Pitfalls

Section titled “Precautions and Common Pitfalls”

Skipping verificationAlways implement verification feedback loops

Comparison with Alternative Approaches

Reference Links

  • Claude Code Official Repository
  • Boris Cherny on X/Twitter
  • Original Thread
  • Ralph-Wiggum Plugin
  • Claude Code Documentation

Summary

Section titled “Summary”

Boris Cherny’s Claude Code workflow demonstrates that maximum productivity comes from:

  1. Compound thinking - Knowledge accumulates and compounds over time
  2. Verification loops - Quality feedback improves output 2-3x
  3. Opus 4.5 exclusivity - Larger models are faster overall
  4. Parallel execution - 15-20 instances working simultaneously
  5. Shared knowledge bases - Team learning through Git-synced CLAUDE.md

The setup might be “surprisingly vanilla” in configuration, but the methodology represents a sophisticated rethinking of AI-assisted development—transforming from single-shot interactions to a continuously learning, parallel-processing, verification-driven development ecosystem.

“The granularity of productivity has been completely transformed. In the past, we were discussing how to write a good function, while Boris is discussing how to schedule an intelligence matrix composed of 20 Opus 4.5s.”

— 码上盈 | AI陪你做生意

Available on both Anthropic Skilljar and Coursera, this free course bridges the gap between basic AI assistance and professional-grade AI-powered development workflows.

“This course covers Claude Code, a command-line AI assistant that uses language models to perform development tasks.” — Anthropic

1. Context is King

Section titled “1. Context is King”

The course emphasizes that effective context management is the single most important skill for using Claude Code productively. The /init command and CLAUDE.md files aren’t conveniences — they’re essential tools.

2. Start Simple, Scale Gradually

Section titled “2. Start Simple, Scale Gradually”

Beginners are encouraged to:

  • Start with basic file operations
