Claude HUD: Real-Time Session Visibility for Claude Code

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

TL;DR: Claude HUD by jarrodwatts is a Claude Code plugin that displays real-time session information — context usage, tool activity, agent status, and todo progress — right below your input. No separate window, no tmux required, updates every ~300ms.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Have you ever found yourself mid-conversation with Claude Code, wondering:

  • How much context do I have left?
  • Which subagent is stuck on what task?
  • What tools has Claude been using?

Claude HUD answers all these questions at a glance. It’s a heads-up display that shows exactly what’s happening in your Claude Code session, always visible below your input area.

What Exactly is Claude HUD?

Section titled “What Exactly is Claude HUD?”

Claude HUD is a plugin that extends Claude Code’s statusline API to provide real-time session visibility. It works by:

  1. Reading Claude Code’s native token data (not estimates)
  2. Parsing the transcript for tool/agent activity
  3. Updating the display every ~300ms

Key Insight: Unlike external monitoring tools, Claude HUD uses Claude Code’s built-in statusline API — meaning it works in any terminal, requires no separate window or tmux setup, and displays accurate data directly from the source.

Installation (3 Steps)

Section titled “Installation (3 Steps)”

Inside a Claude Code instance, run:

Done! The HUD appears immediately — no restart needed.

What Each Section Shows

Section titled “What Each Section Shows”

Session Info

Section titled “Session Info”
ElementDescription
ModelCurrent model in use (e.g., Opus 4.5, Sonnet 4)
Context barVisual meter with color coding (green → yellow → red)
Config countsNumber of CLAUDE.md files, rules, MCPs, and hooks loaded
DurationHow long the session has been running

Tool Activity

Section titled “Tool Activity”
  • Running tools show a spinner with the target file
  • Completed tools aggregate by type with counts

Agent Status

Section titled “Agent Status”

Shows agent type, current task, and elapsed time.

Todo Progress

Section titled “Todo Progress”
  • Current task or completion status
  • Progress counter (completed/total)

Why Real-Time Visibility Matters

Section titled “Why Real-Time Visibility Matters”
Use CaseHow Claude HUD Helps
Context managementSee your context fill before auto-compaction hits
Agent debuggingKnow exactly which subagent is doing what
Performance monitoringIdentify which tools are being called most frequently
Todo trackingWatch task completion in real-time without asking

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Context Health Monitoring

Section titled “1. Context Health Monitoring”

Watch the context bar as you work. When it approaches ~80%, consider:

  • Using /compact focus: "current task" to trim unnecessary history
  • Checking which files are consuming the most tokens
  • Asking Claude to summarize long conversations

2. Agent Awareness

Section titled “2. Agent Awareness”

When using multi-agent workflows, Claude HUD helps you:

  • See which agents are running simultaneously
  • Identify if an agent is stuck (elapsed time keeps growing)
  • Understand the parallel execution flow

3. Tool Usage Patterns

Section titled “3. Tool Usage Patterns”

Over time, you’ll notice patterns:

  • Which tools you use most frequently
  • Whether certain operations trigger cascading tool calls
  • Opportunities to optimize your workflow

Note: These tools complement each other. Use Claude HUD for at-a-glance monitoring and /context for detailed diagnostics.

Requirements

Section titled “Requirements”
  • Claude Code v1.0.80+
  • Node.js 18+ or Bun
  • Plugin marketplace access

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

HUD not appearing

Section titled “HUD not appearing”
  1. Verify Claude Code version: claude --version
  2. Run /claude-hud:setup again
  3. Check that the plugin is installed: /plugin list

Context bar seems inaccurate

Section titled “Context bar seems inaccurate”
  • The bar uses Claude Code’s native token data
  • Slight variations from billing are expected
  • Use /context for detailed breakdown

Agents showing “(long time)”

Section titled “Agents showing “(long time)””
  • This may indicate a stuck agent
  • Consider interrupting and retrying the task
  • Check the agent’s input for potential issues

Section titled “Architecture”

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Claude HUD is a small plugin with a big impact: it makes the invisible visible. By showing context usage, tool activity, agent status, and todo progress in real-time, it gives you the situational awareness needed to use Claude Code more effectively.

Whether you’re a heavy user of agents, working with large codebases, or just want better visibility into your sessions, Claude HUD is worth installing.

Claudian: An Obsidian Plugin That Embeds Claude Code as a Sidebar Chat Interface

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

TL;DR: Claudian by YishenTu embeds Claude Code as a sidebar chat interface in Obsidian, giving your vault full agentic capabilities — file read/write, bash commands, vision support, MCP servers, and multi-step workflows — all while seamlessly integrating with your notes.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

If you’re like me, your Obsidian vault is more than just a note-taking app — it’s your second brain, your project hub, your knowledge base. Now imagine having Claude Code’s full AI agent capabilities integrated directly into that workspace.

That’s exactly what Claudian delivers. It’s an Obsidian plugin that embeds Claude Code as a sidebar chat interface, turning your vault into Claude’s working directory with complete agentic capabilities.

Why this matters: Unlike traditional chatbots or simple AI assistants, Claudian gives Claude actual agency — it can read, write, and edit files in your vault, execute bash commands, use tools, run multi-step workflows, and even connect to external services via MCP. All while staying contextually aware of your notes.

What Exactly is Claudian?

Section titled “What Exactly is Claudian?”

Claudian is an Obsidian plugin built on the Claude Agent SDK that brings Claude Code’s capabilities directly into your Obsidian workspace. Think of it as:

  • A Sidebar Chat: Click the bot icon or use the command palette to open Claude in a sidebar panel
  • Full Agentic Power: Claude can read/write files, run bash commands, and execute multi-step workflows within your vault
  • Context-Aware: Automatically attaches your focused note, lets you @mention files, and includes selected text
  • Vision Support: Analyze images via drag-drop, paste, or file path
  • Extensible: Supports slash commands, custom instructions, skills, and MCP servers

Key Insight: This isn’t just a chat interface — it’s Claude Code running inside Obsidian with your vault as its working directory.

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. Full Agentic Capabilities

Section titled “1. Full Agentic Capabilities”

Leverage Claude Code’s complete power within your Obsidian vault:

CapabilityDescription
File OperationsRead, write, and edit files in your vault
Bash CommandsExecute shell commands with approval safety
Multi-step WorkflowsClaude can plan and execute complex tasks
Tool UseFull access to Claude’s tool ecosystem

2. Context-Aware Chat

Section titled “2. Context-Aware Chat”

Claudian makes Claude contextually aware of your work:

  • Auto-attach focused note: The note you’re viewing is automatically included as context
  • @mention files: Type @ to attach other files from your vault
  • Selection awareness: Selected text is automatically included in conversations
  • Image support: Drag-drop, paste, or reference images by path
  • External directories: Configure context paths for read-only access outside your vault
  • Exclude by tag: Prevent sensitive notes from auto-loading

3. Inline Edit Mode

Section titled “3. Inline Edit Mode”

Select text in your editor and use a hotkey to edit it directly with Claude:

  • Word-level diff preview shows exactly what changed
  • Read-only tool access provides context without modifications
  • Apply changes with a single click

4. Slash Commands

Section titled “4. Slash Commands”

Create reusable prompt templates triggered by /command:

  • Argument placeholders (e.g., {topic})
  • @file references for context
  • Optional inline bash substitutions
  • Override model and allowed tools per command

5. Instruction Mode (#)

Section titled “5. Instruction Mode (#)”

Add custom instructions directly from chat input:

  • Type # to enter instruction mode
  • Refine system prompts on-the-fly
  • Review and edit in a modal before saving

6. MCP Support

Section titled “6. MCP Support”

Connect external tools and data sources via Model Context Protocol:

  • Transport types: stdio, SSE, HTTP
  • Context-saving mode: Enable with @server-name
  • @-mention activation: Trigger MCP servers inline
  • Claude Code compatible: Share configs with Claude Code

7. Advanced Model Control

Section titled “7. Advanced Model Control”
  • Model selection: Haiku, Sonnet, or Opus
  • Custom models: Configure via environment variables
  • Thinking budget: Fine-tune extended thinking tokens
  • Context gauge: Real-time context window usage display

8. Plan Mode

Section titled “8. Plan Mode”

Toggle read-only exploration before implementation:

  • Press Shift+Tab to enter Plan Mode
  • Claude explores codebase without making changes
  • Presents a plan for your approval
  • Implements after you confirm

9. Robust Security

Section titled “9. Robust Security”
  • Permission modes: YOLO (bypass prompts) or Safe (require approval)
  • Safety blocklist: Block dangerous bash commands
  • Vault confinement: File tools limited to your vault with symlink-safe checks
  • Export paths exception: Allow writes to specified directories (e.g., ~/Desktop)

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Option 1: Install from Release (Recommended)

Section titled “Option 1: Install from Release (Recommended)”
  1. Download the latest release from GitHub Releases
  2. Create a folder called claudian in your vault’s plugins folder:
  1. Copy main.js, manifest.json, and styles.css into the folder
  2. Enable in Obsidian: Settings → Community plugins → Enable “Claudian”

Option 2: Install from Source

Section titled “Option 2: Install from Source”

Then enable the plugin in Obsidian settings.

Architecture

Section titled “Architecture”

Security Considerations

Section titled “Security Considerations”

Claudian implements several security layers:

  1. Vault Restriction: File tools and Bash commands are limited to the vault directory
  2. Path Validation: Uses realpath to prevent symlink escapes
  3. Command Blocklist: Platform-specific dangerous command patterns
  4. Approval System: Safe mode requires approval per tool call
  5. Export Paths: Write operations to external paths are explicit and configurable
  6. Context Paths: Read-only access to external directories
  7. No Telemetry: No additional tracking beyond your configured API provider

The plugin is actively developed with an extensive roadmap:

  • Chat history persistence across restarts

  • File context awareness

  • Model selection
  • Permission modes (YOLO/Safe)
  • Image support
  • Inline edit feature
  • Slash commands
  • Instruction mode
  • Skills support
  • Context paths
  • Distributed storage
  • Windows support
  • MCP server support
  • Plan mode
  • Auto title generation
  • Hooks and other advanced features

Getting Started

Section titled “Getting Started”
  1. Install Claude Code CLI if you haven’t already
  2. Install Claudian using one of the methods above
  3. Configure your API key in Claudian settings
  4. Open the chat and try: "Analyze my current note and suggest improvements"
  5. Explore Plan Mode with Shift+Tab for read-only exploration

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Claudian represents a significant step forward in AI-assisted knowledge work. By bringing Claude Code’s full agentic capabilities into Obsidian, it transforms your vault from a static note repository into an interactive workspace where Claude can read, write, analyze, and collaborate — all while maintaining deep context awareness of your work.

Whether you’re writing documentation, managing projects, or building a knowledge base, Claudian offers a powerful new way to work with AI that feels natural, integrated, and genuinely useful.

Oh My OpenCode: Claude Code on Steroids - The Ultimate AI Agent Harness

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI-powered development tools, OpenCode has emerged as a formidable open-source alternative to commercial AI coding assistants. But if you’re a hacker who loves customization and maximum control, Oh My OpenCode is the plugin that transforms OpenCode into something extraordinary.

Created by developer code-yeongyu after spending $24,000 worth of tokens on personal development with various AI tools, Oh My OpenCode represents the distillation of countless hours of testing, configuration, and real-world usage. It’s described by its author as “OpenCode on steroids” — and for good reason.

“If Claude Code does in 7 days what a human does in 3 months, Sisyphus does it in 1 hour. It just works until the task is done. It is a disciplined agent.” — B, Quant Researcher

What is Oh My OpenCode?

Section titled “What is Oh My OpenCode?”

Oh My OpenCode is a comprehensive plugin for OpenCode that adds:

  • Async Subagents — Run multiple AI agents in parallel, just like Claude Code
  • Curated Agents — Pre-configured specialist agents with optimal models
  • Crafted Tools — LSP and AST grep tools for powerful code manipulation
  • Curated MCPs — Built-in Model Context Protocol servers for extended capabilities
  • Claude Code Compatibility — Full compatibility layer for Claude Code configs

The plugin is battle-tested in production environments and has already helped developers accomplish remarkable feats:

“Knocked out 8000 eslint warnings with Oh My Opencode, just in a day” — Jacob Ferrari

“I converted a 45k line tauri app into a SaaS web app overnight using Ohmyopencode and ralph loop.” — James Hargis

Meet Sisyphus: The Default Agent

Section titled “Meet Sisyphus: The Default Agent”

At the heart of Oh My OpenCode is Sisyphus, the default orchestrator agent named after the Greek mythological figure condemned to roll a boulder up a hill for eternity.

“In greek mythology, Sisyphus was condemned to roll a boulder up a hill for eternity as punishment for deceiving the gods. LLM Agents haven’t really done anything wrong, yet they too roll their ‘stones’—their thoughts—every single day. My life is no different. Looking back, we are not so different from these agents.”

Sisyphus’s Toolkit

Section titled “Sisyphus’s Toolkit”

Sisyphus comes equipped with a powerful set of tools and teammates:

Teammates (Curated Agents):

  • Oracle (GPT 5.2 Medium) — Design and debugging
  • Frontend UI/UX Engineer (Gemini 3 Pro) — Frontend development
  • Librarian (Claude Sonnet 4.5) — Official docs and codebase exploration
  • Explore (Grok Code) — Fast codebase exploration with contextual grep

Built-in Tools:

  • Full LSP/AstGrep support for decisive refactoring
  • Todo Continuation Enforcer — Forces agents to finish tasks
  • Comment Checker — Prevents excessive AI-generated comments
  • Claude Code Compatibility — Commands, agents, skills, MCPs, and hooks
  • Curated MCPs: Exa (web search), Context7 (official docs), Grep.app (GitHub search)
  • Async agents with background execution
  • Session management and recovery

Key Features

1. Multi-Agent Orchestration

Section titled “1. Multi-Agent Orchestration”

2. LSP and AST Tools

Section titled “2. LSP and AST Tools”

Unlike other AI harnesses that limit agent access to code analysis, Oh My OpenCode gives agents full access to:

  • lsp_hover — Type info and documentation
  • lsp_goto_definition — Jump to symbol definitions
  • lsp_find_references — Find all usages across workspace
  • lsp_document_symbols — Get file symbol outline
  • lsp_workspace_symbols — Search symbols by name
  • lsp_diagnostics — Get errors before building
  • lsp_rename — Rename symbols across workspace
  • ast_grep_search — AST-aware code pattern search
  • ast_grep_replace — AST-aware code replacement

3. Ralph Loop

Section titled “3. Ralph Loop”

Inspired by Anthropic’s Ralph Wiggum plugin, the Ralph Loop is a self-referential development loop that runs until task completion:

The loop detects <promise>DONE</promise> to know when complete and auto-continues if the agent stops prematurely. It supports all programming languages and can be configured with custom iteration limits.

4. Claude Code Compatibility

Section titled “4. Claude Code Compatibility”

Oh My OpenCode provides a comprehensive compatibility layer for Claude Code:

  • Hooks Integration — PreToolUse, PostToolUse, UserPromptSubmit, Stop
  • Config Loaders — Commands, Skills, Agents, MCP configs from standard locations
  • Data Storage — Todo management and transcripts in Claude Code format
  • Compatibility Toggles — Fine-grained control over which features to enable

5. Context Management

Section titled “5. Context Management”

Intelligent context management features:

  • Context Window Monitor — Alerts at 70%+ usage
  • Preemptive Compaction — Compacts session at 85% usage (enabled by default)
  • Anthropic Auto Compact — Automatic summarization at token limits
  • Tool Output Truncator — Prevents one search from eating your entire context

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Do I need all AI subscriptions?

A: No! You can use Oh My OpenCode with just one provider. The plugin supports Claude, ChatGPT, and Gemini, but you pick what you have.

Q: Is this suitable for beginners?

A: The plugin is powerful but can be complex. The author recommends including ultrawork in your prompts — the agent will handle optimization automatically.

Q: How does this compare to AmpCode?

A: Oh My OpenCode is heavily influenced by AmpCode and Claude Code, with features ported and often improved. It’s designed for the open-source OpenCode platform.

Q: Can I use this with existing Claude Code configs?

A: Yes! The Claude Code compatibility layer means your existing configurations, hooks, and skills should work out of the box.

SivaLabs Marketplace: Supercharge Spring Boot Development with Claude Code

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Claude Code has rapidly become a powerful AI-powered development companion, and its extensibility through plugins and MCP servers opens up incredible possibilities for specialized development workflows. Enter SivaLabs Marketplace - a curated collection of plugins designed specifically for Java and Spring Boot developers.

Created by K. Siva Prasad Reddy (sivalabs), a well-known Spring Boot author and educator, this marketplace brings enterprise Java development patterns directly into your AI-assisted coding experience.

What is SivaLabs Marketplace?

Section titled “What is SivaLabs Marketplace?”

SivaLabs Marketplace is a plugin collection for Claude Code that focuses on Spring Boot application development using the Java, Spring Boot, and Spring Data JPA technology stack. It provides specialized skills that automate common development tasks while following established best practices and architectural patterns.

The marketplace is currently in active development (as of January 2026) and includes the spring-boot-dev plugin as its flagship offering.

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Getting started with SivaLabs Marketplace is straightforward:

After installation, you can verify the plugin and its skills are available using the /plugins command in Claude CLI.

Available Skills

Section titled “Available Skills”

The spring-boot-dev plugin includes five specialized skills that streamline Spring Boot development:

1. spring-boot-package-structure-creator

Section titled “1. spring-boot-package-structure-creator”

Creates the recommended package structure for Spring Boot projects following best practices. This skill ensures your project starts with a solid architectural foundation.

2. jpa-entity-creator

Section titled “2. jpa-entity-creator”

Automates the creation of JPA entities with proper annotations, relationships, and best practices. Simply describe your entity requirements, and the skill generates production-ready entity classes.

3. spring-data-jpa-repo-creator

Section titled “3. spring-data-jpa-repo-creator”

Generates Spring Data JPA repository interfaces for your entities, including custom query methods when needed.

4. spring-service-creator

Section titled “4. spring-service-creator”

Creates Spring service layer classes with proper dependency injection, transaction management, and business logic separation.

5. spring-rest-api-creator

Section titled “5. spring-rest-api-creator”

Builds Spring MVC REST API controllers with appropriate annotations, request/response handling, and validation.

Practical Example

Section titled “Practical Example”

Here’s how you can use SivaLabs Marketplace to quickly build a CRUD REST API:

  1. Create a Spring Boot project with Web, Validation, Spring Data JPA, and H2 dependencies
  2. In Claude CLI, prompt: “Implement CRUD REST API for Person with id, name, email and phone fields”
  3. The plugin will automatically generate:
    • JPA Entity (Person.java)
    • Repository interface (PersonRepository.java)
    • Service layer (PersonService.java)
    • REST Controller (PersonController.java)

Each generated component follows Spring Boot best practices and integrates seamlessly with the others.

Included MCP Server

Section titled “Included MCP Server”

The marketplace also includes the context7 MCP server, which provides general library documentation lookup capabilities. This enhances Claude Code’s ability to reference official Spring documentation and other libraries during development.

Best Practices and Use Cases

Section titled “Best Practices and Use Cases”

When to Use SivaLabs Marketplace

Section titled “When to Use SivaLabs Marketplace”
  • New Spring Boot Projects: Quickly scaffold properly structured projects
  • CRUD Operations: Generate standard create, read, update, delete APIs
  • Learning Spring Boot: See best practices in generated code
  • Prototyping: Rapidly build working APIs for testing and validation

Tips for Effective Use

Section titled “Tips for Effective Use”
  1. Start with Package Structure: Use spring-boot-package-structure-creator first to establish your project layout
  2. Describe Entities Clearly: When using jpa-entity-creator, provide detailed field specifications including types, constraints, and relationships
  3. Review Generated Code: While the plugins follow best practices, always review and adjust generated code to match your specific requirements
  4. Use Context7: Leverage the included MCP server for accessing up-to-date Spring documentation

Building Production-Grade AI Agentic Systems: The 7 Core Architectural Layers

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Modern agentic AI systems, whether running in development, staging, or production, are built as a set of well-defined architectural layers rather than a single service. Each layer is responsible for a specific concern such as agent orchestration, memory management, security controls, scalability, and fault handling.

A production-grade agentic system typically combines these layers to ensure agents remain reliable, observable, and safe under real-world workloads.

The Two Critical Aspects of Agentic Systems

Section titled “The Two Critical Aspects of Agentic Systems”

There are two key aspects that must be continuously monitored in an agentic system:

  1. Agent Behavior - reasoning accuracy, tool usage correctness, memory consistency, safety boundaries, and context handling
  2. System Reliability & Performance - latency, availability, throughput, cost efficiency, failure recovery, and dependency health

Both are essential for operating multi-agent systems reliably at scale.

The 7 Core Architectural Layers

Section titled “The 7 Core Architectural Layers”

Layer 1: Modular Codebase Architecture

Section titled “Layer 1: Modular Codebase Architecture”

Python projects that start small often become messy as they grow. Production-grade systems adopt a Modular Architecture approach:

Layer 2: Dependency & Settings Management

Section titled “Layer 2: Dependency & Settings Management”

Dependency Management uses pyproject.toml instead of simple requirements.txt:

  • Core Dependencies: FastAPI, LangChain/LangGraph, SQLAlchemy, Observability tools
  • Development Dependencies: Black, isort, flake8, ruff for code quality
  • Version Pinning: Using >= operators to avoid dependency hell

Settings Management follows environment-based configuration:

Layer 3: Data Persistence Layer

Section titled “Layer 3: Data Persistence Layer”

SQLModel combines SQLAlchemy (database interaction) with Pydantic (data validation):

Layer 4: Security & Safeguards

Section titled “Layer 4: Security & Safeguards”

Rate Limiting with endpoint-specific rules:

Input Sanitization prevents injection attacks:

  • Email sanitization
  • String sanitization
  • Password strength validation

Layer 5: Service Layer for AI Agents

Section titled “Layer 5: Service Layer for AI Agents”

LLM Service with Resilience Patterns:

Key Features:

  • Connection pooling for database efficiency
  • Automatic retry with exponential backoff
  • Circuit breaker pattern for cascading failure prevention
  • Model fallback for resilience

Layer 6: Multi-Agentic Architecture

Section titled “Layer 6: Multi-Agentic Architecture”

LangGraph Stateful Agent with:

Components:

  • State Management: PostgreSQL-based checkpointing for crash recovery
  • Memory Integration: mem0ai with pgvector for long-term memory
  • Tool Execution: DuckDuckGo search integration
  • Observability: Langfuse tracing for every step

Layer 7: API Gateway & Authentication

Section titled “Layer 7: API Gateway & Authentication”

FastAPI Dependency Injection for security:

DevOps & Observability

Section titled “DevOps & Observability”

Containerization Strategy

Section titled “Containerization Strategy”

Monitoring Stack

Section titled “Monitoring Stack”
  • Prometheus: Metrics collection (request rate, error rate, latency)
  • Grafana: Visualization dashboards
  • cAdvisor: Container resource monitoring
  • Langfuse: LLM tracing and evaluation

Evaluation Framework

Section titled “Evaluation Framework”

LLM-as-a-Judge

Section titled “LLM-as-a-Judge”

Automated Evaluation System:

Metrics Tracked:

  • Hallucination detection
  • Toxicity filtering
  • Relevancy scoring
  • Helpfulness assessment

Architecture Stress Testing

Section titled “Architecture Stress Testing”

Simulating 1,500 Concurrent Users

Section titled “Simulating 1,500 Concurrent Users”

Test Results:

Key Insights:

  • Model fallback (switching_model_fallback) kept service alive
  • Connection pooling prevented database exhaustion
  • Rate limiting protected downstream APIs

Actionable Takeaways

Section titled “Actionable Takeaways”

  1. Start Modular - Separate concerns from day one. Don’t wait for the codebase to become messy.

  2. Design for Failure - Implement retry logic, circuit breakers, and model fallbacks before you need them.

  3. Observability First - If you can’t measure it, you can’t improve it. Integrate tracing from day one.

  4. Test at Scale - Local testing isn’t enough. Simulate real concurrent loads before production.

  5. Memory Matters - Short-term (context window) and long-term (vector store) memory both matter for agentic systems.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Building production-grade AI agentic systems requires attention across 7 architectural layers: from modular code structure and data persistence to security safeguards, resilient AI services, multi-agent orchestration, API gateways, and comprehensive observability.

The distinction between a prototype and production isn’t just about features—it’s about reliability under load, observability into behavior, and resilience when things fail.

You can explore the complete implementation at FareedKhan-dev/production-grade-agentic-system

Pulse: OpenTelemetry-Native Digital Experience Platform for Real-Time User Monitoring

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Pulse is an open-source digital experience platform that combines behavioral, technical, and business insights to drive better user experiences. Built on OpenTelemetry standards with native mobile SDKs for Android and React Native, real-time monitoring, and self-hosted deployment—giving you complete control over your observability data. Here’s everything you need to know in 5 minutes.

The Modern Observability Challenge

Section titled “The Modern Observability Challenge”

Traditional monitoring tools tell you when your servers are down. APM solutions track API response times. But what about the actual user experience?

Enter Pulse—a platform that monitors every screen, interaction, and API call to give you insights into what your users actually experience in real time. It’s like having a microscope on user behavior combined with X-ray vision into your application’s performance.

1-Minute Knowledge Cards

Section titled “1-Minute Knowledge Cards”
ConceptWhat It Means
Digital Experience PlatformMonitors user behavior + technical performance + business metrics in one view
OpenTelemetry NativeBuilt on OTel standards for vendor-neutral, portable observability
Critical InteractionsTrack the user journeys that matter most—checkout flows, login sequences, content engagement
App VitalsCrash/ANR tracking, frozen/slow frame detection, network performance monitoring
Self-HostedDeploy on your infrastructure with full data ownership (MIT licensed)

Main Content

Section titled “Main Content”

Core Highlights

Section titled “Core Highlights”

1. Real-Time User Experience Monitoring

Unlike traditional monitoring that focuses on backend metrics, Pulse captures the actual user experience:

  • Screen-by-screen health tracking
  • User experience scoring across segments
  • Real-time visualization of performance degradation

2. OpenTelemetry Native Architecture

Built from the ground up on OpenTelemetry standards:

  • Vendor-neutral data collection
  • Portable telemetry that works across platforms
  • Compatible with 90+ observability tools
  • Future-proof observability investment

3. Mobile-First SDKs

Native support for mobile applications:

  • Android SDK (pulse-android-otel): OpenTelemetry instrumentation for Android apps
  • React Native SDK (pulse-react-native-otel): Cross-platform mobile monitoring
  • Automatic instrumentation with minimal configuration

4. Intelligent Alerting

Get notified when it matters:

  • Customizable threshold-based alerts
  • Multi-channel notifications (email, Slack, webhook)
  • Alert history with trend analysis
  • Context-rich notifications for faster debugging

5. ClickHouse-Powered Analytics

High-performance analytics backend:

  • Sub-second queries on massive datasets
  • Real-time aggregations and filtering
  • Efficient time-series data handling
  • Scalable architecture for growing platforms

Technical Architecture

Section titled “Technical Architecture”

Backend Stack

  • Java 17 with Vert.x for high-performance async I/O
  • MySQL for transactional data storage
  • ClickHouse for analytics and time-series queries
  • OpenTelemetry Collector for telemetry ingestion

Frontend Stack

  • React 18 with TypeScript
  • Mantine UI for modern, accessible components
  • Real-time updates via WebSocket connections

Mobile SDKs

  • Kotlin for Android with OpenTelemetry SDK
  • React Native for cross-platform support
  • OTLP protocol for standard telemetry export

Key Features Deep Dive

Section titled “Key Features Deep Dive”

Critical Interactions Tracking

Section titled “Critical Interactions Tracking”

Not all user actions are equal. Pulse lets you monitor the interactions that drive your business:

App Vitals Monitoring

Section titled “App Vitals Monitoring”

Understand application health at a glance:

  • Crash-free users: Track stability across versions
  • ANR (Application Not Responding): Detect UI freezes
  • Frame rendering: Identify slow/frozen frames affecting UX
  • Network performance: Monitor API latency and failure rates

User Growth KPIs

Section titled “User Growth KPIs”

Segment your users by experience quality:

Identify problem segments by device, region, OS version, or custom attributes.

  • 4GB RAM minimum (8GB recommended for production)

Pro Tips

Section titled “Pro Tips”
  • Start with Critical Paths: Don’t try to monitor everything. Identify your top 3 business-critical user journeys and instrument those first.
  • Use Custom Attributes: Enrich telemetry with user segments, subscription tiers, or any business-relevant metadata for powerful filtering.
  • Set Meaningful Thresholds: Alert thresholds should reflect actual user impact, not arbitrary technical metrics.
  • Correlate with Business Metrics: Pulse is most powerful when combined with revenue, retention, or conversion data.
  • Leverage OpenTelemetry: Since Pulse uses OTel, you can export to multiple backends simultaneously—Pulse for UX monitoring, Grafana for infrastructure, etc.

Second Brain AI Assistant: Open-Source Course for Building Agentic RAG Systems

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Explore Decoding ML’s open-source course that teaches you how to build a production-ready Second Brain AI assistant using LLMs, RAG, agents, and LLMOps best practices.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Imagine asking your AI assistant to recommend agent courses, list top PDF parsing tools, or summarize LLM optimization methods—all based on your personal research, without manually searching through your notes. This is the promise of the Second Brain AI Assistant concept.

Created by Paul Iusztin and the Decoding ML team, this open-source course teaches you how to build a production-ready agentic RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) and LLM system from scratch.

Repository: decodingai-magazine/second-brain-ai-assistant-course

Course Series: Build Your Second Brain AI Assistant

What is a Second Brain AI Assistant?

Section titled “What is a Second Brain AI Assistant?”

The Second Brain concept, popularized by Tiago Forte, refers to your personal knowledge base of notes, ideas, and resources. A Second Brain AI Assistant leverages this knowledge to:

  • Answer questions based on your research
  • Summarize documents from your knowledge base
  • Provide insights by connecting your notes
  • Recommend resources you’ve curated

While the course uses Notion as the data source, the architecture is adaptable to other sources like Google Drive, Calendar, or custom databases.

Section titled “Course Overview”

This comprehensive course contains 6 modules covering theory, system design, and hands-on implementation:

  10. Agent Building - Using smolagents
  11. Modern Python Tooling - uv and ruff

Slash Commands Collection: 13 AI-Powered Developer Productivity Commands

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

As AI coding assistants become essential tools for modern developers, the ability to customize and streamline their behavior through slash commands has emerged as a powerful productivity booster. The slash-commands collection by regenrek offers a curated set of 13 battle-tested commands designed specifically for code review, problem analysis, and refactoring workflows. Let’s explore this comprehensive toolkit that works across Claude Code, Cursor, and Codex.

What is the Slash Commands Collection?

Section titled “What is the Slash Commands Collection?”

The slash-commands repository is a carefully curated collection of AI-powered slash commands created by Kevin Kern, a developer focused on building tools that enhance AI-assisted coding workflows. The collection addresses common pain points developers face when working with AI coding assistants:

  • Code review consistency - Standardized reviews across team members
  • Problem diagnosis - Systematic bug identification and impact analysis
  • Refactoring workflows - Structured approaches to code improvements
  • Planning and organization - Task management and documentation practices

Each command is designed as a Markdown template that can be invoked with a simple /command-name syntax, making complex workflows repeatable and shareable across teams.

Installation Guide

Section titled “Installation Guide”

For Claude Code Users

Section titled “For Claude Code Users”

Claude Code supports both project-specific and personal commands:

Project commands (shared with your team):

Personal commands (available across all projects):

For Cursor Users

Section titled “For Cursor Users”

For Codex Users

Section titled “For Codex Users”

Complete Command Reference

Section titled “Complete Command Reference”

1. /create-plan - Comprehensive Task Planning

Section titled “1. /create-plan - Comprehensive Task Planning”

Purpose: Creates structured implementation plans with all necessary sections before development begins.

Usage:

Features:

  • Context and problem statement
  • Measurable success criteria
  • Clear deliverables and approach
  • Risk assessment and testing strategy
  • Cross-references to AGENTS.md for rules/constraints

When to use: At the start of new features or complex tasks to ensure comprehensive planning.

2. /plan-review - Implementation Plan Review

Section titled “2. /plan-review - Implementation Plan Review”

Purpose: Reviews implementation plans and provides a go/no-go decision for development.

Usage:

Evaluates:

  • Codebase alignment and current patterns
  • Scope clarity and completeness
  • Performance, security, and privacy impact
  • Code smells and potential caveats

When to use: Before starting complex implementations to validate your approach.

3. /finalize-plan - Task Completion Documentation

Section titled “3. /finalize-plan - Task Completion Documentation”

Purpose: Finalizes completed tasks by creating finished plan files and lightweight summaries.

Usage:

Features:

  • Moves task to finished directory with status
  • Creates lightweight summary file (SOW - Summary of Work)
  • Cross-references between plan and summary
  • Tracks affected files, tests, and decisions
  • Token-optimized for AI consumption

When to use: When tasks are completed to maintain organized documentation.

4. /code-review-low - Fast Code Review

Section titled “4. /code-review-low - Fast Code Review”

Purpose: Lightweight code review focusing on critical issues only.

Usage:

Focus Areas:

  • Code smells and security vulnerabilities
  • Performance bottlenecks
  • Essential test coverage

Output:

  • Summary with top 1-3 risks
  • Decision: approve | request_changes | blocker
  • Findings grouped by Smell | Security | Performance | Tests
  • Exact file and line range references

When to use: After implementing features for quick validation.

5. /code-review-high - Thorough Code Review

Section titled “5. /code-review-high - Thorough Code Review”

Purpose: Comprehensive code review with extended analysis for major changes.

Usage:

Includes: All code-review-low checks plus:

  • Deeper security and performance analysis
  • Comprehensive test recommendations
  • Architecture and design pattern review
  • Dependency and integration analysis

When to use: For major changes or before releases.

6. /problem-analyzer - Bug Identification and Impact Analysis

Section titled “6. /problem-analyzer - Bug Identification and Impact Analysis”

Purpose: Identifies bugs and maps affected files across the codebase.

Usage:

Provides:

  • Root cause analysis
  • File impact assessment
  • Minimal safe fix proposals
  • Documentation gap identification

Pro tip: Works best when combined with error logs and a short problem description. Consider using with faster models like Cheetah for quick analysis, then switching to more capable models for detailed solutions.

When to use: During debugging sessions for faster issue resolution.

7. /refactor-code - Structured Refactoring Workflows

Section titled “7. /refactor-code - Structured Refactoring Workflows”

Purpose: Initiates refactoring workflows with clear scope and isolation.

Usage:

Features:

  • Feature-specific refactoring scope
  • Commit isolation guidelines
  • Documentation of unrelated issues (without fixing)
  • No backward compatibility or feature flags

When to use: When starting refactoring work to maintain clean commit history.

8. /kill-port - Port Management Utility

Section titled “8. /kill-port - Port Management Utility”

Purpose: Kills processes running on specified ports with OS-specific commands.

Usage:

Features:

  • Cross-platform support (macOS, Linux, Windows)
  • Process identification and verification
  • Safety warnings for system processes
  • Graceful shutdown recommendations

When to use: When ports are occupied and need to be freed up.

9. /research-better-lib - Library Evaluation Framework

Section titled “9. /research-better-lib - Library Evaluation Framework”

Purpose: Comprehensive template for evaluating alternatives to baseline libraries.

Usage:

Features:

  • Structured problem statement and success metrics
  • Search query templates for benchmarking
  • Candidate library shortlist evaluation
  • Minimal benchmark design guidelines
  • Decision rubric and deliverables checklist

When to use: When considering library replacements to find modern, faster alternatives.

10. /ask-codefetch - Codebase Context Gathering

Section titled “10. /ask-codefetch - Codebase Context Gathering”

Purpose: Gathers narrowed codebase context into a single markdown file using codefetch.

Usage:

Workflow:

  1. Research: identify relevant files/directories for the task
  2. Generate: run codefetch with scoped files → single .md file
  3. Read: use codefetch/codebase.md as context

When to use: When you need to provide context to an AI about specific parts of your codebase.

11. /ask-codefetch-pro - Quick Codebase Analysis

Section titled “11. /ask-codefetch-pro - Quick Codebase Analysis”

Purpose: Generate codebase, copy to clipboard, and automatically open AI chat.

Usage:

When to use: For quick codebase analysis with automatic clipboard and browser integration.

12. /solidjs-rules - SolidJS Best Practices

Section titled “12. /solidjs-rules - SolidJS Best Practices”

Purpose: Comprehensive SolidJS coding rules and best practices.

Usage:

Covers:

  • Reactivity basics and signal usage
  • Control flow helpers (Show, For, Switch)
  • Async and side effect patterns
  • Component API and prop guidelines
  • Styling conventions
  • File and folder organization
  • ESLint configuration examples

When to use: When working with SolidJS codebases to ensure best practices.

13. /component-cleanup - SolidJS Component Structure

Section titled “13. /component-cleanup - SolidJS Component Structure”

Purpose: SolidJS component size and structure rules for code cleanup.

Usage:

Guidelines:

  • Component size guidelines (150-250 LOC target, 600 LOC hard cap)
  • File naming conventions
  • Component splitting strategies
  • Logic extraction to hooks/utilities
  • JSX nesting limits

When to use: When reviewing or refactoring SolidJS components.

14. /short-tokens - Token Optimization

Section titled “14. /short-tokens - Token Optimization”

Purpose: Minimizes token usage while retaining all key information.

Usage:

Principles:

  • Trim aggressively for token savings
  • Retain every key fact, figure, and conclusion
  • Remove redundancy and filler
  • Avoid ** asterisk formatting
  • Every token consumes space in agent token windows

When to use: When optimizing text content for AI token windows.

Recommended Workflow Integration

Section titled “Recommended Workflow Integration”

Daily Development Workflow

Section titled “Daily Development Workflow”
  1. Morning Planning: Use /create-plan for new tasks
  2. Pre-Implementation: Use /plan-review to validate approach
  3. During Development: Use /problem-analyzer when bugs appear
  4. Post-Implementation: Use /code-review-low for quick validation
  5. Major Milestones: Use /code-review-high before releases
  6. Task Completion: Use /finalize-plan to document outcomes

Team Collaboration

Section titled “Team Collaboration”
  • Share commands through project-level .claude/commands/ directories
  • Standardize reviews using /code-review-low or /code-review-high
  • Document decisions using /finalize-plan summaries
  • Debug together using /problem-analyzer with shared logs

SolidJS Projects

Section titled “SolidJS Projects”
  • Use /solidjs-rules for onboarding new developers
  • Apply /component-cleanup during code reviews
  • Combine both for comprehensive SolidJS quality checks

Comparison with Built-in Alternatives

Section titled “Comparison with Built-in Alternatives”
Featureregenrek slash-commandsClaude Code Built-in /review
Code Review LevelsTwo: low (fast) and high (thorough)Single level
CustomizationFully editable Markdown templatesFixed prompt
Planning FocusDedicated /create-plan, /plan-reviewNot included
Problem AnalysisSpecialized /problem-analyzerGeneral debugging
RefactoringStructured /refactor-code workflowNot specialized
Cross-PlatformClaude Code, Cursor, CodexClaude Code only
CommunityOpen source, forkableProprietary

Tips and Best Practices

Section titled “Tips and Best Practices”
  1. Start Simple: Begin with /create-plan and /code-review-low for immediate value
  2. Customize: Edit the Markdown templates to match your team’s conventions
  3. Version Control: Commit your custom commands alongside your code
  4. Combine Workflows: Chain commands together (e.g., /create-plan → /plan-review → /code-review-low)
  5. Document Patterns: Use /finalize-plan to create reusable patterns for future work

About the Author

Section titled “About the Author”

Kevin Kern (@kregenrek | kevinkern.dev) is the creator of the slash-commands collection and founder of instructa.ai, where he teaches developers how to build software with AI.

Related Projects:

  • codex-1up - OpenAI Codex Tools
  • AI Prompts - Curated AI Prompts for Cursor AI, Cline, Windsurf and Github Copilot
  • codefetch - Turn code into Markdown for LLMs
  • aidex - CLI tool for AI language model information

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

The slash-commands collection by regenrek transforms AI coding assistants from generic tools into personalized, team-oriented productivity systems. By providing 14 carefully crafted commands covering planning, review, debugging, refactoring, and optimization, this collection addresses real workflows that developers face daily.

Whether you’re working solo or part of a team, these commands help maintain consistency, catch issues early, and document decisions effectively. The beauty lies in their simplicity—Markdown files that can be customized, shared, and version-controlled alongside your code.

Start with /create-plan and /code-review-low, then gradually incorporate more commands as your team’s needs evolve. Your future self (and your teammates) will thank you for the investment in standardized, efficient workflows.

Compound Engineering Plugin: Official Claude Code Plugin That Makes Each Unit of Engineering Work Easier

Jan 3, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Compound Engineering Plugin: Official Claude Code Plugin That Makes Each Unit of Engineering Work Easier

Section titled “Compound Engineering Plugin: Official Claude Code Plugin That Makes Each Unit of Engineering Work Easier”

“Each unit of engineering work should make subsequent units easier—not harder.”

In traditional software development, every feature added makes the next feature harder to build. More code means more edge cases, more interdependencies, and more complexity. This accumulation of technical debt is the default trajectory for most codebases.

EveryInc’s compound-engineering-plugin for Claude Code inverts this paradigm. It implements a compound engineering methodology where each unit of work makes future work easier through a systematic learning loop.

Introduction and Key Features

Section titled “Introduction and Key Features”

The compound-engineering-plugin is an official Claude Code plugin developed by EveryInc that orchestrates AI agents to plan, write, review, and compound engineering knowledge. The plugin embodies a revolutionary approach to software development where:

  • 80% of effort goes into planning and review - ensuring thorough understanding before code is written
  • 20% goes into execution - leveraging AI agents for code generation
  • Knowledge compounds over time - each lesson learned feeds back into the system

Key Highlights

Section titled “Key Highlights”
FeatureDescription
Four-Step WorkflowPlan → Work → Review → Compound → Repeat
Multi-Agent OrchestrationParallel agents handle research, implementation, and review
Knowledge CompoundingLearnings are systematically captured and reused
Worktree ManagementIsolated development environments for each feature
Open SourceMIT licensed, fully auditable and customizable

Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration

Section titled “Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Claude Code installed and configured
  • Git for worktree management
  • GitHub CLI (gh) for repository operations

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

The installation process is straightforward:

Initial Configuration

Section titled “Initial Configuration”

Once installed, the plugin provides four main workflow commands:

CommandPurpose
/workflows:planTurn feature ideas into detailed implementation plans
/workflows:workExecute plans with worktrees and task tracking
/workflows:reviewMulti-agent code review before merging
/workflows:compoundDocument learnings to make future work easier

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

When to Use Compound Engineering

Section titled “When to Use Compound Engineering”

This methodology excels in these scenarios:

  1. Solo Developers Building Products - One developer can achieve what traditionally required a team of five
  2. Complex Feature Development - Multi-component features that require careful planning
  3. Knowledge-Intensive Codebases - Projects where context and patterns matter significantly
  4. Long-Term Projects - Projects where compound effects have time to accumulate

Daily Workflow Example

Section titled “Daily Workflow Example”

Here’s how a typical compound engineering session flows:

Step 1: Plan (80% of the value)

Section titled “Step 1: Plan (80% of the value)”

The agent:

  • Researches the codebase and commit history
  • Scours the internet for best practices
  • Synthesizes a detailed implementation plan
  • Identifies potential pitfalls and edge cases

Step 2: Work (20% of the value)

Section titled “Step 2: Work (20% of the value)”

The agent:

  • Creates an isolated worktree
  • Implements according to the plan
  • Writes tests alongside code
  • Tracks task completion

Step 3: Review (Critical checkpoint)

Section titled “Step 3: Review (Critical checkpoint)”

Multiple agents:

  • Review the code independently
  • Catch issues and suggest improvements
  • Evaluate against established patterns
  • Verify all acceptance criteria

Step 4: Compound (The magic happens)

Section titled “Step 4: Compound (The magic happens)”

The agent:

  • Documents lessons learned
  • Captures new patterns discovered
  • Updates project knowledge base
  • Feeds insights back into the system

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Never skip the Plan phase - This is where most value is created
  2. Always Review before merging - Multiple perspectives catch more issues
  3. Document everything - Future agents depend on this knowledge
  4. Trust the process - The compound effect takes time to manifest

Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Important Considerations

Section titled “Important Considerations”

⚠️ Learning Curve

The compound engineering approach requires a mindset shift. Traditional developers accustomed to “just coding” may find the emphasis on planning unfamiliar.

⚠️ Initial Investment

The first few cycles will feel slower than traditional development. This is normal - you’re building the knowledge foundation that future cycles will leverage.

⚠️ Tool Requirements

Full benefits require Claude Code with the plugin installed. The methodology is tool-agnostic in theory but optimized for this stack.

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is this only for solo developers?

A: No. While Every uses it to enable solo developers to build complex products, teams can benefit even more from the systematic knowledge capture and multi-agent review process.

Q: Does this work with existing codebases?

A: Yes. The Plan phase includes researching your existing codebase, making it effective for both greenfield and brownfield projects.

Q: Can I use this with other AI coding tools?

A: The plugin is designed for Claude Code, but the compound engineering philosophy is tool-agnostic. Some Every team members also use OpenAI’s Codex CLI.

Q: What happens if the plan is wrong?

A: The Review and Compound phases capture why the plan didn’t work, feeding that learning back into future planning cycles.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”
IssueSolution
Plugin not foundEnsure marketplace is added before installing
Worktree conflictsClean up existing worktrees with git worktree prune
Agent hallucinationsUse Review phase with multiple agents to catch issues
Slow performanceConsider reducing research scope in Plan phase

Collaboration with Similar Products and Comparative Analysis

Key Differentiators

Section titled “Key Differentiators”

  1. Knowledge Compounding as First-Class Citizen - Most tools focus on code generation; compound engineering focuses on making future work easier

  2. Multi-Agent Review - Leverages multiple AI perspectives to catch issues that single-agent approaches miss

  3. Systematic Learning Loop - Every lesson is captured and fed back into the system

  4. 80/20 Planning-to-Execution Ratio - Inverts the traditional emphasis on coding speed

Integration Possibilities

Section titled “Integration Possibilities”

The compound engineering plugin can integrate with:

  • CI/CD pipelines - Use Review phase as a gate before deployment
  • Documentation tools - Automatically feed Compound outputs into knowledge bases
  • Project management - Track worktrees as tasks/features
  • Code quality tools - Combine with linters, formatters, and security scanners

Real-World Impact

Section titled “Real-World Impact”

EveryInc runs five software products in-house, each primarily built and run by a single person using compound engineering:

“Today, if your AI is used right, a single developer can do the work of five developers a few years ago, based on our experience at Every.”

— Dan Shipper & Kieran Klaassen, Compound Engineering: How Every Codes With Agents

These aren’t demos - they’re products used by thousands of people daily for important work.

Whether you’re a solo developer or part of a team, this approach offers a path to sustainable, compounding productivity gains.
